Gimme.bio:
Diagnosed by GP as possible PMR Nov 2022.  Classic pattern of hip, buttocks, thighs stiffness and pain, sides of knees and extreme debilitating fatigue, plus muscles became very tired after little effort.  Inflammatory markers not raised.  RA, lupus and fibromyalgia excluded.  Then Jan 2023, caught flu and triggered shoulder, neck and upper arm pain, unable to turn my head so started pred 15 mg Feb 2023 with miraculous results, completely free from pain and stiffness within hours.  After 15mg for 2 weeks, reduction to 10mg due to psych effects and then again after a week to 7.5 mg. In May reduced to 5mg as still suffering side effects.  Pain and stiffness did not start to return until 5 mg, but still 80-90% effective.  Extreme fatigue returned after dropping to 5 mg.  Vit D at 4,000 IU helped fatigue noticeably.

I blame my PMR on years of work stress and personal trauma.  Became so ill May 2021, forced to stop work and take early retirement.  Now starting to suspect that viral infections trigger a flare in PMR symptoms and also possible strong dietary correlation.  Also learned, Do whatever makes you happy (if I had enough energy).

Was always athletic and fit, ran, walked, cycled, swam, I had walked to 18,000 ft in the Himalaya when all this started.  Classic atopic family with asthma, eczema and hayfever allergies.  Have always had problems with my muscles, which I put down to sporting injuries and pattern of physio, osteopathic treatments. 

Hard to say when my symptoms first started, possibly as long ago as 2003.  I can’t pinpoint first flare, but stiffness and tiredness started in my early 40s, physio advised seeing a rheumatologist, but GP did not take very seriously.  Prescribed diclofenac, as effective as pred is now, but effectiveness only lasted a few weeks, so did not persist.  Since then, every few months, I have had a flare of same symptoms, stiffness, pain, fatigue, which lasts a few months and then disappears, although stiffness persisted.  I have an idea that the flares correlate to viral infections, but too long ago to be sure, or possibly stress.  Many visits to GP, but nothing done until GP in Nov 22.

First really bad attack happened around 2007, could hardly walk due to stiffness and pain, coinciding with flare of eczema on my arms and severe GI symptoms.  GI symptoms investigated and nothing found so labelled IBS.  I suspected diet and tried FODMAPs diet, which helped GI symptoms.  Then eliminated wheat and the pain, stiffness, brain fog, palpitations, fatigue vanished within 48 hrs.  Have been gluten free since.  Though continued to get flares of PMR type symptoms; hip girdle and rotator cuff type pain.  Stopped work May 2021, at the time, I thought due to stress and mental health, but now know that there is an underlying physical reason.  Summer 22 was hell for me, for months could not get up stairs, classic PMR Donald Duck waddle, toddler stomp down the stairs and old person groaning noises to get me out of a chair.  Saw GP in Nov 22 as wondered why I was not recovering from what I thought was a stress burnout and that is when I got a tentative diagnosis.  New GP and first one to take it all seriously.  The flare was tapering off at the end of the year without treatment by the time I saw the GP, but I got flu in Jan 2023 and all the symptoms kicked off again.  The worst it has ever been.  This time, my neck, trapezoid and shoulders, upper arms affected aswell as the hip girdle, lower back and legs etc.  I was a complete mess and could hardly move, so finally gave in and went on the pred.  

I can’t say that the pred is wonderful for me, or that my quality of life is better.  The control of pain and stiffness is slightly better than taking ibuprofen, but I hate the way that pred makes me feel.  If I could stop the pred tomorrow, I would, in a heart beat.

Diet seems to be majorly important for me.  I was prediabetic last year and when I was on the prediabetes diet, my symptoms were significantly better during that time.  When I went on pred, I went back to eating foods with low Glycaemic Index and my weight has been stable.  When I lapse, I have discovered that I am extremely sensitive to added sugar, alcohol less so, very reactive to fried high carb snacks like crisps and tortilla crisps with loads of additives.  I really suffer the next day and a day or so after lapsing.

For now, I am continuing with the pred and trying to taper, and at the same time continue to explore the diet.  I am certain that I have PMR, but I also suspect that my dietary intolerance might have worsened, exacerbating the PMR symptoms.  Lastly, many PMR sufferers are anaemic, so I plan to try some iron to see if that helps the debilitating tiredness.

In case you wonder about the screen nick, I tried about 20 names when I joined and each one I tried was already taken. I finally tried gimmestrength in frustration, which was also taken 😃, so this is what I ended up with.  It would seem that finding an acceptable user name to join the site is more difficult than finding a cure for PMR.

Updated 05 July 2023.

Blood results from 5 Sept 2023:
CRP less than 5 mg/l
ERS 14 mm/h
Rheumatoid factor less than 10 iu/ml
Anti-nuclear factor negative (less than 1/100)
Iron, B12, folate and Vit D levels OK.
T4 and TSH normal
Hb a1c 39 mmol/mol - so 9 months pred hasn't put me back in the pre-diabetes zone yet. 
Weight fairly stable but put on 2 or 3 lbs.
FBC all within acceptable range.
Neutrophils 7.84 (normal range 1.5-7.2) - slightly raised due to pred?

So on the face of it, I look pretty healthy.  So why do I feel so crap then?  I made a list of my symptoms and they covered 2 sides of A4.  Saw the nice lady GP today and she still thinks that my symptoms sound like PMR, but there is still some random stuff going on (dryness, worsening asthma and thyroid) that doesn't fully fit.  She is going to speak to rheumatology about possibility of Sjogrens and is also sending me for a neck scan to look at my thyroid.  Thyroid function was normal, but I have an enlarged painful thyroid gland, it seems.

Updated 27 Sept 2023.

Tumorboy20.bio:
I had a brain scan through a work related annual physical that showed a mass on the brain.  After going to MD Anderson in Houston, they performed a surgical procedure through the top of my skull by removing a (appropriately 3 inch x 5 inch) bone flap from the top of my skull.  After returning home, I noticed some drainage that was discolored and went to the hospital to have it checked out.  Long story short, several surgeries (8) later most of which were subsequent infections due to the material that the Dr.  used to replace the bone flap (PEEK) I went to consult another physician and he advised me that the material is a good material for most people however once you get an infection from it you are prone to subsequent infections.   He did a surgical procedure by replacing the bone flap with a titanium mesh with titanium screws and that seemed to due the trick.  
Fast forward 6 months and they determined that the tumor returned and decided to do radiation therapy.  I received radiation for 6 weeks, 5 days/week.   After that, about a year later, the tumor was still there and they advised that a form of radiation called TruBeam was the best course of action.  It was a single treatment.  

A month after that, I began to have effects such as loss of balance/coordination.  It was determined that I had lessons (areas of brain necrosis) on the brain that was causing this.  

They advised that I should treat with medication including infusions of avastin bi-weekly.   I have been doing those for the past 2-3 months with no significant improvement.  

Close to 5 years later, I am still looking for suggestions.  Any help would be greatly appreciated

Bodypump51.bio:
I am what I thought was a fit individual until I was diagnosed with severe stenosis of the mid LAD artery with associated angina. 
My cardiac journey has been one that has received virtual no attention by the NHS and had to move to the private pathway to see a cardiac consultant and have the needed stress MRI. 
Am now followed up by a practice nurse annually - never been seen in a NHS cardiac clinic. 
Suffered a vasovagel event which triggered a severe cardiac spasm leading to hospitalisation. Reviewed by private cardiologist, no treatment change but advised to sip water throughout the day. Resumed normal fitness with PT shortly after and body pump resumed after a month.

LAJ12345.bio:
Hi, I am the wife of a person with Parkinson’s. He is now 60, diagnosed April 2018. 58.  We have been following this site since then, trialling every new thing that comes up on here that seems safe.

He has had many tests done through a naturopath at House of Health in Auckland including DNA analysis, blood tests, organic acids urine test, SIBO breath test, hair analysis for heavy metals, faeces test for bacteria, viruses and parasites. Naturopath used opus 23 to analyse DNA results.

My husband’s genetic testing says he has a large requirement for b1, b2 and b6. He had an improvement to his facial expressions on B1 but after trialling various concentrations, up to 3 g per day he has now settled on 1000mg per day.  He takes mannitol, d-ribose, b2, and hardy’s inositol, dissolved in water that he sips on throughout the day.   

He had been on mirtazapine for a few years which made him sleepy and apathetic. He weaned off that over 3 months last year but became extremely anxious and suicidal around Christmas 2018 and had to be treated by the acute mental illness hospital. They put him on sertraline and back on mirtazapine.  He was even worse on the sertraline and became agitated and had insomnia then the mirtazapine calmed him down again but he was back to being apathetic and sleepy.

Finally I put him on Hardy’s  daily nutrients in February and this has had the single biggest positive impact of anything he has tried yet including the pharmaceutical drugs.   Hardy’s  is a clinic trialled, balanced vitamin and mineral supplement. He takes the sipper bottle with the extra vitamins in addition to the Hardy’s product:

hardynutritionals.com/produ...

He also takes Hardy’s greens and probiotics, Restore Gold since January 2019,  fish oil, digestive enzymes before meals, ubiquinol, pqq.
 Citicoline cdp jarrows on 28/5/19. 
Starting to slowly wean off mirtazapine and sertraline over months. ( now down to 2 mg mirtazipine from 30mg. Using a jewellers scale to reduce by about 1.5 % per week. Sertraline still on full amount 50mg as decreasing it by just a small amount made him feel worse).

1 november 19 now also taking celery seed extract (2 weeks) , niagen (6 weeks) astaxanthin on and off, shilajit(3 weeks), acetyl glutathione (5 weeks), l- carnosine (3 weeks), vinpocetine (1 week), and for roseacea lighthouse probiotics every second week, Allimed (garlic clinical strength) and berberine alternate weeks ( for a year) . 

Update 12 November 19 

The pharmaceuticals he Is on at the moment ( he is weaning off them) are mirtazapine, down to less than 2 mg from original 30mg and sertraline/Zoloft down to 40mg from 50mg. I have a jewellers scale and I am reducing these by a small percentage each week over many months and hope to have him off them again in 6 months. If he seems to feel a bit worse I will add a tiny bit extra back in and wait until he stabilises but so far so good!

At the moment he is feeling better than he has been for years, and is happy energetic and motivated. He is only on 1 C/L per day and we are going to phase that out and swap to mucuna.

Latest supplements which I think have helped his progress lately are pathethine from NOW, and horny goat weed which has 10% icariin in it from planetary herbals which has really ramped up his energy, mood and motivation plus he seems interested in everything again and is busy organising outings, buying stuff, and interacting with people again. I feel we are on the right track. (He is still taking the above supplements too ). 

Probiotic trialing a new one. Lifestream advanced probiotics mood + immunity.  

Also 1/2 kinson C/l  tablet  which seems to have not much effect. He tried up to 3 a day but they make him feel sick so he has settled on 1/2 before breakfast.   Uridine with the C/L seems to help with nausea and juddering.   He is taking 2 mucuna dopa from  NOW with the C/L for 120mg more l-dopa. 


Update 14 feb 2020.  Stopped uridine for a while as he has been taking it a while and supposedly  it may have side effects long term.   kinson C/L still 1/2 per day, mucuna 1 per day,  sertraline/Zoloft down to 1/9 of a 50mg tablet, mirtazapine down to 1% of the original dose. Tried going offthe mirtazapine totally last week but felt bad so staying on this minuscule amount a bit longer.  Overall stable mood, no deteriation, not feeling sick all the time now, more energy, less apathy, but still funny walk, no arm swing, fingers don’t work well.  Urination urgency decreased, libido improved, slight tremor when tired or stressed. No anxiety.


Nothing was really working until he started on the Hardy’s daily nutrients. Within 3 days of starting the DEN he had a remarkable improvement.

I think his initial thiamine regime topped up his thiamine deficiency but then started making him anxious. The Hardy’s is topping up all the other vitamin and mineral deficiencies.

Previously I had been trying to replicate the Hardy’s formula with individual doses of the vitamins and minerals and other supplements like nac, etc where they were available to buy separately but when I swapped them all out for the Hardy’s product the difference was night and day. I am not sure if it is because Hardy’s is Canadian made and quality tested where the other supplements are from places like China so the quality may not have been there or whether it is that the Hardy’s DEN have traces of many minerals that can’t be purchased separately. ( my husband had a heavy metal hair analaysis and his arsenic and mercury levels were at the top end of the low band so I was concerned the arsenic may have been from contamination in his previous supplements).

Anyway I urge any of you who are taking a lot of the ingredients in this product individually to swap them out for this product.

marionofnorwich.bio: Diagnosed in early lockdown first with a persistent pain between my shoulder blades and then my neck wouldnt turn and it was hard getting out of bed or from the sofa. Treatment by the osteopath ( when i could finally see him) was ineffective. That's when i phoned the doctor. A physio diagnosed PMR over the phone. I had never heard of it but on Googling realised my symptoms matched. Started on 15mg of pred (plus a load of supporting pills) in August 2020 and a few days later was back to whizzing about feeling normal again. A typical story. Reduced quite well down to 4mg until a dose of Covid in April 2022 sent my body into tailspin. The Covid wasnt bad but the impact meant a big flare. I didnt know about sickday rules, flares or anything else and floundered around with no guidance, following my instincts as no real guidance. GPs were not well informed I realise now. An agonising pain in my knee like it had been hit by a hammer turned out to be an insufficiency fracture of the knee end of my femur (used to be called bone necrosis, not a nice thought). Now have tapered again to 4mg but feel rough most days and legs very stiff and painful but cant work out what is PMR, or four years of low levels of exercise, or other issues such a what seems to be an inflamed varicose vein in my lower leg which flares every week or two for a few days. Rheumatologist says to continue taking 4mg permanently. Doesn't think my adrenals will work again. Now take statins and blood pressure medication. Feel a mess generally as i try and problem solve my condition and what to do about it. Professionals not much help so employing trial and error methods

shihtzu124.bio: My husband was diagnosed with prostate cancer in 2018. His PSA bounced around  between 4 and 6 then rose to 7 in late 2018. He had a RP in January 2019.  Gleason 4+3 with clean margins. There was an area of perineural invasion but supposedly no extension outside of the prostate. His PSA was undetectable for several years then over the past few years it has slowly risen from 0.01 to 0.2. His latest doubling time is 11 months. We started speaking with a RO earlier this year who suggested 6 mo ADT and 2 months later begin 35 salvage radiation treatment. This is suggested to begin shortly after he hit the 0.2  PSA level. So here we are faced with a very difficult decision.  His PSMA-PET scan last week (11/28/23) was negative. He has no symptoms. He is concerned about potential side effects of radiation.  The ADT that has been suggested is orgovyx and only for 6 months, so hopefully those SE's will be transient. But the short and long term SE's of radiation make it a tough choice for someone who is otherwise healthy, very active and not having any symptoms.  SO what is weighing heavily on him, is the question How much QoL will he have to give up in hopes of a possible "cure".  I should mention that we are going to try to schedule a second opinion from Cleveland clinic or Moffitt Cancer Center to help him make his decision on the best next steps. I am here to listen to everyone's stories and support my husband as best that I can.

707twitcher.bio:
I am a buprenorphine “convert”.  It greatly eased my withdrawal from pramipexole after being on it for 12 years.  And it completely relieves my RLS symptoms.

I still experiment with alternatives because of the typical opioid side effects.  I’m now using gabapentin, as it finally seems to help my RLS.  I tried it and pregabalin earlier but I think my dopamine receptors were too damaged.  I still use buprenorphine, but in a smaller dose.

Sunset.bio:
I would like to give you some information about maladia Behçet’s Disease, one of the serious diseases in our age.

I got Behçet's disease in 1985 and in February 1987, the doctors of Istanbul University Capa Medical Faculty diagnosed this disease. I used the drugs given by the doctors, but it did not work well for my medication, it did not help to relieve symptoms such as scrotum open wound, alpha, Erythema nodosum and pseudofolliculitis. As a health worker, I knew that there was no specific treatment for this disease, I had symptoms of Erythema nodosum in my lower extremities. This was the beginning of some of the rheumatic problems that formed the other symptoms of the disease. I was worried that I would have complications experienced by some other patients with the disease. In April 1988, I read many medical books to learn more about Behcet's disease, its symptoms and complications. I am very glad that there is a close relationship between the composite I made and the cause of the disease. It is a mixture that is used in pharmacology and has no side effects and provides radical treatment in terms of its pharmacodynamic properties and its physiological and biochemical properties. After applying it on myself, I definitely got rid of the disease. I haven't had any problems so far. It is very easy to explain this scientifically, I would like to meet with pharmaceutical companies that conduct research on Behçet's disease. Hoping to apply the radical treatment of Behçetin, not symptomatic; With all respect.

FortyWinks.bio:
Presented to GP with frequent need to pee. Assumed aged related prostate issue. Shocked to find advance PC.  With hindsight, some symptoms,  sciatic type pain, hip pain, breathlessness and tiredness. Gleason score of 9. Started on Degaralix by Urologist  and agreed Enzalutamide best option with Oncologist. PSA down from 233 to virtually undetectable. Scans show mets stable. Side effects of treatment pretty grim at times so meds to deal with those then other side effects. Probably at limit of impact on quality of life but glad to be here nonetheless. 

PSA has been slowly rising over the past 9 months or so from virtually undetectable to 1.6 at latest review 27 Nov 23.
Oncology not concerned as yet but has indicated if it continues at this rate and when it reaches 4 then it will be time to look at other treatment options.  I am not wanting to ‘worry twice’ but I would like to have a good understanding of what the options are before that discussion.  Hoping that perhaps other options become available before then and can be included.

Worried, of course but trying my best not to feel overwhelmed.  Worrying for the family too.

jillygirl.bio:
Hello everyone.  I am an administrator for Quit support. I joined quit support on the 5th April2011. I have been  quit for over 12 years now.I am married  have 2 grown up daughters and 2 teenage grand daughters.  I  am 75 years old. act about 7 years old at times. lol. :) 
I  was diagnosed with lung cancer  september2012 .I had the whole of my right lung removed early December.   Apart from being  short of breath  with anything  physical I haven't looked back. Thanks  to quit support and the lovely community. I   had a heart attack in  2013, no surgery required. I then got a secondary cancer on the adrenal gland, in 2014. surgery and chemotherapy.  now at the moment cancer free.  
 I now have a pacemaker fitted (6th January 2017) My aim is to get fitter and keep out of hospital.
All you quitters  stop now  dont let old nic beat you.  
Message to all , stop smoking  and stay strong.   BIG thank you to all on quit support.   xx
Update  19/04/2018   discharged from oncology , no Cancer showing on CT scan.  All clear! :) x

Joolsg.bio:
Hi, I'm Jools. 
Female. Born 1960. Based in UK.

I've had RLS since 1997 and Multiple Sclerosis since 1994. RLS is by far my worst MS symptom, probably caused by spinal lesions and neuron damage. I've tried every herbal remedy, diet & device around. I was on Ropinirole for years but suffered augmentation & had a very difficult withdrawal. I also tried gabapentin & pregabalin & Oxycontin but still had very severe RLS I pushed for buprenorphine & it has been miraculous. Zero RLS since I started it in July 2021. I am now Campaigning to get RLS taught to the medical profession & buprenorphine & methadone licensed in the UK for RLS.
I take Buprenorphine 0.4mg (0.2 mg at 9 pm and 0.2mg at midnight). I take 25mg pregabalin to counter opioid panic attacks and 10mg cetirizine for opioid sweats. I also start an MS drug soon which is a chemotherapy. Hopefully it won't worsen RLS.

Entwicklung.bio:
41y/o male... I'm very lucky I've got everything; wife, kids, cats, dogs, great family and friends - the lot. However, my health has been suffering for years now and feels in steep decline of late. I've seen many specialists trying to find an answer to my problems Inc cardiologist, haematologist, neurologist, haematologist, gastroenterologist and currently endocrinologist. I've been diagnosed as heterozygous for  hemochromatosis but this shouldn't be causing my current issues. A long list of symptoms here, which I'm sure make me sound crazy:

1. Fatigue - exercise is intolerable for my body. After exercise is when it hits me and daily tasks are even becoming difficult.
2. High heart rate - it jumps up at the slightest movement and is even high when I'm sleeping now. Worse in the heat and with stress and definitely upon eating. On researching it often seems to have 'POTS' element to it.
3. Pain /pressure in the RHS of my neck. Also noticed my head tilts to this side.
4. 'Kidney' pains - dull aches, but sometimes sharp and seems to increase in line with HR and other issues.
5. Blood pressure - increasing all the time. 
6. Brain fog - lots of cognitive issues and working memory is almost none existent.
7. Eyes - bright lights cause me issues, and my pupils open and close when shining a light into them (pupilliary Hippus I believe it's called)
8. Gastro problems - eating smaller meals helps, otherwise it increases HR significantly, feels very uncomfortable and food seems to stay in the stomach for hours. 
9. Abdominal pains - very sharp and random stabbing pains... These are sporadic and only last a second.
10. Stress intolerance. 
11. Sleep problems - I can get to sleep fine, but wake at 2-3am and can't return to sleep. 

I've had many blood tests and the only significant clues I have currently are low cortisol and high ferretin so I'm pursuing those. I'm hoping I'm near to an answer so I can get back to enjoying life🤞 

UPDATE: Found a knowledgeable cardiologist in Wigan recently who has put the pieces of the puzzle together... I'm very lucky to have found him. He's diagnosing me with hypermobility (potentially EDS(?)) with Dysautonomia... We need more tests to find out the exact types and systems that are affected. That's all I know so far, but will update as I go in case it's useful for others in future.

Goldy700.bio: I remember getting RLS when I was in my early 20's and going to a movie theatre and needing to leave because my legs were playing up.  I have had it on the mild side ever since but this year it has escalated to an alarming degree.  I am 69.  I have always been conscious of not eating sugar, going gluten free, eating healthy balanced food.  However this year, the only thing that allows me to sleep is a hot bath, hot shower or a barefoot walk on cold wet grass.  I tried Gabapentin and it did nothing for me.  Maybe the dose was too low at 100mg. However after reading that it can cause augmentation I am determined to try to cope without drugs, until they can invent one that does not make things worse in the long run which I think would cause me to go around the twist.  I don't get it in the day which is a blessing.   I seem to be able to get enough sleep most nights but wake up 2 - 3 times a night and have to treat with bath, or barefoot walk.  I am grateful to this community as there is great advice on so many issues.  I am especially interested in people's experience with natural cures.

Spanielmadlady.bio: Hi...I'm a mum of 2 ,nanna of 2 and  a pet parent of 1 madcap springer spaniel. I turned 50 during lockdown which was abit surreal.my journey officially started at xmas 2013. A chest infection led to pleurisy in both lungs,in and out of hospital scans etc couldn't find anything so I asked for a 2nd opinion.specialist diagnosed bronchiectasis and heart failure.struggling to improve I was sent to a regional lung centre where professor of respiratory told me to come off steroids.i did and after 3 months everything started to flare.i was stiff in a morning etc so gp sent my to rheumatology routine tests flagged up something in my urine so off to renal clinic where biopsy showed class 5 lupus nephritis. I now take hydroxchloroquine,prednisolone and mycophenolate amongst a ton of other meds for my heart and lungs.with hindsight I think I've had lupus alot longer I've always been a tired person and suffered alot of fatigue and over the years had various things no dr could diagnose.at one point I was told it was all in my head.ive had positive DS-DNA and ANA but these are currently negative.the thinking is now the lupus is responsible for my heart and lung problems.every day is a battle with fatigue,concentration,joint pain etc .my  spaniel keeps me moving through it all and gives that bit of unconditional comfort on bad days.being prone to pneumonia I hibernate in winter so lockdown has been a doddle as I'm expert at keeping occupied when I'm not having a sleep day that is .i cant work now i lost my job in jan 2015 as i worked in an high infection unit .keep smiling and we will get through

Maxone73.bio:
Well, still trying to accept the fact that I am stage 4, giving that I am in great great shape (for now). As AI researcher, I like to look for everything that can give myself (and others) some hope! Oh I am an ex natural bodybuilder (I still work out quite hard for my age) so if you need tips I can try to help.

Age 50 (1973)
Diagnosed with stage 4 on 23/08/2023 with PSA = 70, small bone metastasis (>4) and lymph node metastasis
- Started straight away with Casodex (20 days) then started Decapeptyl on 09/09/2023 and continued with Casodex to avoid tumor flare

On 28/09/2023 my PSA = 15, and I started with ARASENS protocol: ADT (Decapeptyl) + Docetaxel (6 cycles) + Darolutamide
PSA
3 after first chemo infusion
1.5 after second chemo infusion
1.01 after the third chemo infusion 
1.8 after the fourth chemo infusion but measured under different conditions (strenuous workouts for two days in a row, one week after chemo instead of 3 weeks as usual)...scared like hell
0.4 after the fifth chemo...thank God
0.39 after the sixth chemo! (3 weeks after the chemo, 01 Feb 2024)
0.07 (28 March 2024)
0.05 (9 May 2024)
0.06 (13 June 2024, they say normal fluctuations)
0.03 (08 Aug 2024) 
0.03 (05 Sept 2024)
0.02 (31 Oct 2024)
0.01 (28 Nov 2024)


Testosterone level on 01 Feb 2024: 0.33 nmol/L
Testosterone level on 13 June 2024: 0.50 mol /L, again they said normal fluctuations
Testosterone level on 31 Oct 2024. 0.33 nmol/L

Last PET scan (13 June) says I am still in remission, metastasis are still decreasing after almost 6 months without docetaxel.


Waiting for my genetic tests to come back (they came back...see below).

I proposed ARASENS to my MO but he already wanted to do it and convinced Bayer to add me to the trial after a good fight! I hope it's the best decision, looking at their numbers it is, it should give me at least 5 years without progression (hopefully) and in 5 years god knows which new treatments will be available...at least I hope!

My supplement plan is as follows:

General health supplements:
I use vegan high-quality protein powder after workouts, a practice I've maintained throughout my 32 years of heavy-duty workouts (though not as intense lately!). I only consume it in moderation. On workout days, I aim for 0.8-1.0 g of protein per kg of ideal weight. 
Recommendation: The "per kg of body weight" indicated on labels can be misleading. Someone might weigh 100 kg with 40% fat or 100 kg with 5% fat. If you only consider body weight, you might end up feeding fat in the former case.

General health/microbiome:
A healthy gut appears to be associated with better cancer treatment outcomes and is certainly linked to overall health. I enjoy vegetables and have recently added: pomegranate juice (around 100ml almost daily without a fixed schedule), homemade sauerkraut (occasionally store-bought), miso soup (when I remember), boiled beetroot with beans, and I try to consume as much fiber as possible (including a teaspoon of unsweetened cocoa powder).

Chemo/adt therapy: I avoid supplements 48 hours before and 72 hours after chemo. This is a precaution to prevent any interference with the treatment or PSA readings. Many studies suggest substances like curcumin can enhance chemo, but these studies are mostly conducted on cells or mice. Since 90% of such research fails when tested on humans, I weigh the risks: potential benefits against potential harm. I choose to err on the side of caution. I wait 72 hours for docetaxel to be fully ineffective before resuming supplements.
My only strategy during chemo is fasting or consuming very low calories (300-400/day) 48 hours before and 24 hours after treatment. This is based on clinical experiments by Valter Longo (you can look him up). I do this primarily to minimize side effects, though it's believed to also protect healthy cells.

Close to chemo sessions (not too close, as mentioned above), I take:

Curcumin and ursolic acid in small doses, twice a day for now. Their antioxidant properties are beneficial for general health. After completing chemo, I plan to reduce this to once daily.
UPDATE post-chemo: I take curcumin, green tea and resveratrol. I quit ursolic acid, I want to switch supplements from time to time. Plus I added sulforaphane and also spirulina (and I eat mre broccoli lately!). 

Silymarin from milk thistle, 240mg daily, starting 48-72 hours post-chemo and stopping 48 hours before the next session. As chemo affects the liver, I use this to aid its recovery. I'll continue using it in the future but for shorter durations.

A combination supplement of calcium, zinc, magnesium, and D3 + K. Calcium, zinc and magnesium are not high doses and don't provide 100% RDA of any component. I planned to stop these supplements once done with chemo, but I am on someta now, so my MO wants me to take D3 and K2 and to make sure I have enough calcium, so I am still supplementing.

Melatonin: I consume 4mg daily for sleep. I came across a Russian clinical study (from a reputable source, in 2012 at least!) suggesting potential long-term survival benefits with a 3mg nightly dose. They administered it to participants only during summer, but I speculate this is because Russians naturally produce more melatonin during their shorter winter days.

CBD oil: for fun!

Broccoli24.bio:
Hi, I'm in the UK and turned 51 this year.
DX early July 2024 - PSA 530 
Shock to the system because zero symptoms. 
Thanks to my girlfriend who made me get a general check up. 
MRI, CT & transPerineal biopsy revealed low volume metastatic PC (spread to lymph nodes but not the bones). 
Gleason 7 (4+3). 
Was immediately put on Degarelix (Firmagon)
Hot flushes and a bit of fatigue - but mild SEs so far.
6 weeks later PSA dropped to 0.88
I'm now a week into Enzalutamide (Xtandi). Hot Flushes have increased. 

I'm also experimenting with supplements. I've spent last 6 weeks reading medical studies & trials 
of various herbs/berberine/black seed oil/etc etc. It's a minefield with info pointing in all directions. 

A friend with a difficult to treat cancer eventually refused chemo/radio/surgery. Instead 
went on a vegan diet, and took various supplements, homeopathic and otherwise. I thought he was ill-advised to 
take that route... Within two years his cancer was gone. That's 12 years ago now, and he's still fit and well. 

So, I've decided to go the full treatment route but incorporating diet/supplements etc. 
I've gone full vegan/wholefood/organic (Wondering about fish for omega 3). I eat between noon and 8pm. 
Cramming in as many anti-inflammatory cancer fighting foods as possible - Cruciferous veg, broccoli sprouts, Curcumin, Beets, pomegranate, etc etc. 
I was a bit over weight but not much... my diet was ok... all home cooked, but lots of eggs and lots of dairy... cream, cheese, yogurt.  I exercised - but not as much as I maybe should have. 
I now get at least 30 mins vigorous exercise daily (mainly swimming), and try to add between 7000/10000 steps throughout the day, so I'm not too sedentary. Exercise feels like medicine. Cold showers too... anti-inflammatory. 

I've been reading this forum for a few weeks now and massively appreciate all you guys 
for how you all handle it... with humour... and with grace. Sharing knowledge seems key. Tho I know everyone doesn't always agree! We're all in the same crappy boat... using whatever paddles we can lay our hands on.  

What supps I'm taking; (Or, intend to take... time and cost means I'm on about a third of the below, I find as each runs out, I follow my gut about what to keep going and what to phase out.)
Black seed oil, Berberine ,Pomi-T, Zyflamend, Resveratrol, Boswelia, Sage leaf extract, Dandelion Tea, Peppermint oil caps,  Vit D3, occasional B12 (because vegan), Aspirin (75 mg every other day), Omega 3 (every other day), Pharmaceutical CBD oil to help sleep, Probiotic capsule, Ground Flaxseeds, 1 tsp Curcumin extract mixed with black pepper & oil. 
I'm considering adding a few more, and may take some of the above away (any advice welcomed); Liposomal Quercetin, Vit K2, Turkey Tail (Fruiting body or Mycelium??), Reishi mushroom, Theracumin, Grape seed extract, Ellagic acid, Sutherlandi Frutscens, Indole 3 carbinol, Sulfurophane, modified citrus pectin, Melatonin, 1tsp bicarb soda daily, Genistein, Silibinin, Triphala (Ayurvedic), grape seed extract.

I'm also thinking about traditional Chinese medicine, to use in tandem with 'western' medicine... quite a few studies point to it increasing efficacy.  But... haven't explored any further. 

Currently 3 months in, on Degarelix & Enzalutamide. PSA down to 0.03... side effects minimal for now. I'm exercising a lot, weights and cardio, and am hoping this is keeping S/Es to a minimum. Radiotherapy to prostate coming up in Jan/Feb.

Anyway, that's about it... thank you... I appreciate you guys!

skipro.bio:
I am an orthopedic  surgeon with relapsed CLL and immune compromise.

I was diagnosed in 2011 but labs from several years prior show I clearly had it longer.  Interestingly, my docs that ordered the labs for other reasons, did NOT notify me of the obvious abnormality.

It was a 7 year roller coaster of start treatment next month, then based on labs, wait repeated dozens of times.

I took a 1 year Sabbatical in 2016 in preparation to start FCR but it was delayed until 2018.   I had closed my practice which took 6 months, so in the interim, I worked at a volunteer clinic and did disability exams until I started FCR in 2018.

10 DAYS AFTER THE FIRST ROUND  FCR I FELT LIKE A NEW PERSON.  ALL MY SYMPTOMS WERE GONE.

The next 2 cycles brought a 5-10 period of feeling sick, then back to feeling amazing.

At cycle 4 I was Neutropenic and remained so for 9 months.  I was on 4 antimicrobials but did not have an opportunistic infections until 6 months later.

I then had a near fatal aspergillis infection inner ear, ethmoid sinsus, with erosion towards the brain.

This was cured with Voriconizole that disrupted my vision and this has never ressolve.

I relapsed at the beginning of Covid and initially the numbers were skyrocketing and based on this and a few other issues  I was told to prepare for a 6-12 month survival.

Things slowed down but I became extremely unwell for a year before I could convince my doc to start treatment.

I started V +O 3 1/2 months ago and felt worse for about 6 weeks then slowly started to improve :).   

I received multiple covid vaccines but did not produce antibodies.  I received Evusheld 3 times but could not do it again because it was deemed ineffective against current strains.

I used extreme caution and despite multiple episodes of Covid like symptoms always tested negative.

I did have a 4 month period of cough, wheezing, shortness of breath and extreme fatigue.  I'm not sure if I tested at the right time.   I was worked up for Richters and adenopathy but there was none that could have been compressing my airway.   

I did test positive for nucleocapsid antibody which led to 2 possibilities including the IVIG I get or long Covid.  Still do not know.

IVIG started with chemo and it miraculously eliminated all my sinus infections which were present literally 11 of 12 months of the year.

I hope and pray for everyone with CLL to be strong, and blessed with positive experiences with the anxiety of watch and worry, and treatments as well as protection from serious infections.

Skipro

RiversW.bio:
My RLS symptoms started when I was in college. However, symptoms did not become severe enough to seek medical attention until I was 32 and living in NYC. Working as a film editor required me sit in a dark room for long periods of time. It sometimes became very challenging to do my job without jumping out of my skin. But I also believe that staring at images moving quickly on a monitor sometimes worked to relax my legs. I know that video games can have that  effect. At other times the symptoms were just too severe to sit still and I would have to take a walk. 

Severe symptoms or perhaps augmentation started about 7 years ago. After napping in the editing room (a common practice in my world because of the extremely long working hours) I would wake feeling horrible all over my body. It's difficult to describe the pain. Perhaps like a bad flu without the fever. After being awake for an hour or so the symptoms would subside.

These symptoms became so severe that I sought out a specialist in RLS. About 5 years ago. This was the first time I heard about augmentation. My neurologist suggested I stop taking Mirapex cold turkey. That didn't work. In fact , I had days 5 of the worst RLS symptoms I had ever experienced. 24/7. After 25 years of RLS  I was already sleep deprived, but this was extreme. I did not sleep for 4 day.s When I started falling asleep  walking I ended my attempt at getting off Mirapex. Too dangerous. My neurologist then put me on Neuupro. For 6 months I was almost free of symptoms. All the old triggers even disappeared. But then the augmentation started again. Over time Itried different dosages of Mirapex and pregabalin to deal with the symptoms, but things went from bad to worse. 

In the meantime, I had moved to Brasil to be closer to my wife's family. A lot of the responsibilities for moving fell on my wife because I was often incapacitated from lack of sleep.  My symptoms continued to get worse. It became common for me to be awake 24 hours 2 days a week. And then the burning started. It felt I had a very severe sunburn on different parts of my body. The burning happened during the day, at night. Anytime. I was at my wit's end. 

Long story made a little shorter, I discovered this site and my neurologist suggested Buprenorphine at about the same time. It has saved my life. Soon I will be free of dopamine agonist completely and hopefully living my life less burdened by RLS.

Trying to withdraw from Neupro and suffering moderate to severe augmentation and rebound.

I have not been diagnosed with PD. I was diagnosed with REM Sleep Behavior Disorder in April 2021. My neurologist said this would eventually become PD, LBD, or MSA. At the time of diagnosis I also had a sore neck, sore left shoulder and upper arm, sore left leg, some balance issues, loss of sense of smell, and seborrheic dermatitis on my face.  I have also had random jerky movements and muscle twitches for many years.
All that said, I feel pretty good. My RBD is nearly non-existent. The involuntary movements are way down. Balance is fine. Left shoulder and are are almost normal. I still have a sore neck and a poor sense of smell.
I can't pinpoint why I am better, as I do a LOT of things: https://rbd-pd-protocols.blogspot.com/p/my-stack.html

nchauf.bio: I suffer from schizoaffective disorder depressive type. I am recovering from a long depressive episode. I am getting better and having a more positive outlook on life. I also have suffered from suicidal ideation and currently have recovered from that. I still struggle and do my best to learn how to manage this illness. I am here to offer support and receive support from people who suffer similar struggles.

Eggy386.bio:
Long time dealing with anxiety, but a lot recent major life events have happened that was greatly heightened anxiety and depression. I also have a couple of medical symptoms that don’t have a clear cut cause because they’re very common, which also drives anxiety and depression.

Currently do not have a lot of outlets for stress and talking about issues, so I’m feeling quite isolated physically and mentally. 


So hear to learn some coping skills, talk to like minded people, and get out of my head a bit.

H4PP1.bio:

Stage IV endo is beginning to ease with the help of diet changes, nutrition and massage.

I have not had any surgery and hope to avoid this.

Musicl.bio: Was reasonably healthy, just mild Asthma, Excema and mild Arthritis until I reached 74 years old (I am now 78) and then had heart attack, diagnosed as MINOCA. Now have Mirovascular Angina. Have Osteoarthritis. Recently had both hips replaced, also knee replacement. In 2018, it was incidentally found that I have a small Splenic Artery Aneurysm, but after being monitored for five years, it had not grown bigger, so was discharged from Cardiovascular care.  Just on the brink of having Carpal Tunnel surgery and under investigation for bowel problems (not cancer).

Shield_Of_Faith.bio:

Pitalife.bio: Hi,been struggling my whole life w bad ,anxiety, anxiety,phobias,and depression,my brother recently  killed himself and I been struggling and caring full x for my last elderly parent..I relocated to south FL to care for her and all my meds and sitchuation  has changed drastic leaving me w more then I can take,currently  struggling w severe anxiety n worsening  depression.. Fiddlemum.bio:
Hi. I started feeling stiff beginning of June 2021. Pain followed in hips then shoulders - by September strange pains and stiffness all over the place. Woke in the night unable to turn over. As for getting dressed - itwas agony. Getting legs in jeans, pulling on a jumper, getting upstairs……..
Changed anti depressant to Venlafaxine @October, then took Ibuprofen on top of that. Ended up with similar issues to when I was given Clopidogril years back. Had a bit of breakthrough spotting from that. It stopped when I switched back to Aspirin. Stopped both of them just now. Since my recent blood tests I’ve gone back to previous anti depressant , Paroxetine 10mg. Spotting/leakage seems to have eased quite a bit. 
Blood tests came back on 21/12 21 - raised CRP and ESR levels. GP has put me on 15mg of Prednisilone. I started it 22/12/21 - it’s made a big difference, thank goodness. I’ve been a bit round the bend worrying about myself because I didn’t know what was wrong. Im now trying to calm down and find out more about this. Very glad to have found this forum. Phew!!

MarchSeventeenth317.bio: Hello, I have been diagnosed with GAD at a relatively young age and I am dealing with some dramatic life changes and would love to talk to people who understand

Recently given Trimbow to use but seem more breathless on this - is this the right treatment?

Green999.bio:
After VAT I feel well. No tumor marker indicates cancer. Oncologist waiting for tumor marker to increase and  I will  have to  start chemo for second time. God help me.
I was refused to receive Bevacizumab in Ontario for plural effusion after waiting 8 months for traitment. Oncologist told me that I will die within 4-5 weeks and that nothing will help me.
I travel to Europe- Bulgaria where I receive Bevacizumab plus Gemcitabin and Cisplatin 8 times. Now my tumor marker is 20 and pleural effusion very little left. I will continue with only Bevacizumab every 4 weeks. 
I am so engry that I cannot return in my country for so long time and cannot be treated in Canada!!!

Sarah770.bio: Mom of three, 2 kids with IVF - French living in Spain

wayoveryonder.bio:
I was diagnosed with Parkinson in January 2023 after having severe symptoms within a short period of time.
It seems that the progress is relatively fast, for example dyskinesia, which I had not expected so soon and also because I still take a low dosage of medication. 
I have read of the vitamin B1-therapie and I have begun with 400 mg per day. 
I exercise relatively often (3 to 4 times a week). 
I was also diagnosed with restless leg syndrom. 
Those leg-symptoms have changed and I have the feeling it is now a real Parkinson-Symptom not a separat condition that is present 24 hours of the day with rigidity in my legs, especialy at night and weakness in the legs during daytime. 
My hope is in the B1-Therapie.

FibChick.bio: Initially diagnosed with SVTs in 2023, then abruptly went into AFIB in fall of 2024. Medications did not get me back to sinus rhythm, cardioversion worked foe two days, then back in ER with AFIB. PFA cardiac ablation helped, but still tweaking meds to get rate and rhythm better controlled. Retired to Florida in 2016, may have been a mistake as best doctors here are overwhelmed with patient load and access / communication not the greatest.

Tiggywoos.bio: In Feb 2020 I developed a severe rash on my face and liver alt was 10 X over limit . GP admitted me to hospital with autoimmune hepatitis but hospital discharged as didn’t agree . Next day had to have emergency steroid injection as swelling so severe.  Like many others on here my journey has been long , frustrating and often painful . Summer of 2020 was diagnosed with SLE but then “undiagnosed “ and changed to UCTD . I have tested positive for scleroderma antibodies on several occasions and IGM but never positive ANA . More recently the rashes are apparently typical of urticarial vasculitis .

ForestryPine6.bio: I'm a man on a journey of weight loss and also for anxiety as the endorphins I get from cycling helps a lot with this. But it's difficult getting motivated. And I find it difficult to lose weight even though I go Mtn Cycling twice a week 25 miles each time. I've not exercised since September 2022 due to be hospitalisation for type 2chronic respiratory failure which meant I couldn't hardly walk but I could eat so want to start this week all over again as my tests continue but I seem to be feeling better, I need to lose 20kgs as I'm 142 kgs currently, it's going to be hard and getting motivated again but I have to else I'm looking at type 2 diabetes, hope on here there's support. Also started going to the Gym for workouts on X-trainer and Weights. I also have lymphodema on both lower legs with water retention so on diuretic tablets early morning everyday.

Challis12.bio: I was diagnosed with CLL 12 years ago.  Genetic testing revealed I had some markers that would be challenging in my treatment success.  I entered a trial and achieved a complete remission which lasted 5 years.  Then the disease returned and I have began a series of Gazyva infusions and am taking Caquence.  I have had a history of sleep issues and anxiety which was pretty much under control with meds, yoga, meditation.  2 months into treatment I feel like the anxiety is getting tougher to manage and my sleep is also going the same route.  I am very frustrated as nothing is noted in the side effects regarding this issues.  I feel brushed off when I mention them to my doctors.

Amore55.bio: I have had MS since 1990. It took awhile to get diagnosed, but that was the determination. I have PPMS. I have been blessed with 8 wonderful children, 19 grandchildren, as of this update, and have a good life full of joy. I struggle often, like all of us, but just keep plugging along. At time of diagnosis, I was told to expect a wheel chair in 5 years, but still walking. I do use an electric chair on lazy leg afternoons, when legs no longer want to cooperate, but mornings are always great.

Quilter449.bio:
Lifelong yoyo dieter.   GP glowers at my BMI and threatens statins.  I am three stone overweight which makes me sad.  I am only 5’ so any excess really shows on me.  Pretty healthy but just can’t keep my weight down.

 Interested in healthy eating and read a lot on the subject.    I belong to a hiking club and do a Pilates class each week.  I have decided to stop running as I kept getting joint problems.  Perhaps speed-walking will be an option.

I  like to sew, knit, crochet, read, watch tv.  However, deteriorating sight means that all this is more difficult.  This ageing game is a bugger!  They say it’s not for the faint-hearted and they are right!

I live alone after coming out of a very long marriage (my choice).  It has its own challenges but it’s largely working for me.  I can’t see me starting again with anyone else.  I like making my own decisions, choosing what to eat and when, and how to spend my time.

Activity2004.bio: I'm a Recreation Assistant at a Senior Center Monday-Friday.  I also love to read and write in my free time.

Purple-Bike.bio:
Diagnosed October 2020 with  Gleason  9, low PSA 1.7.  Partly intraductal. BRCA2+  PSMA-PET/CT showed cancer spread to seminal vesicle and lymph nodes in pelvic region, and suspected mets. 
A month later started EBRT external radiation  and two brachotherapy internal radiation treatments. Firmagon and  Bicalutamide.
 
In April 2021 a new PSMA scan confirmed a single met in the right iliac bone which was spot radiated. Firmagon and Bicalutimade replaced with transdermal estrogen patches.  

After 10.5 months of ADT, in September 2021, went on medication vacation  when I learned that estrogen may accelerate PC growth in the presence of BRCA+.  

In February 2024 a NaF PET/CT showed abnormal uptake in two ribs and the clinic recommended immediate SBRT.   
A second opinion said that cancer recurrence was not certain and recommended me to wait. 

I followed this opinion and had new scans in May 2024 which showed unchanged uptake compared to previous scans and that there are no indications of recurrence. 

PSA ˂0.1  ALP, LDH,  in normal range, Chromogranin A and neuronspecific endolase in normal range. .T = 4 European scale, 110 US scale. 

cfDNA, an imperfect indicator of cancer recurrence, had been around 7 for three years but the last reading showed just 4.5 

New tests in 3 months, new scans in six months.

Two to three times weekly gym sessions mainly all-out weight training plus sprint interval training. 60 minutes biking on non-gym days doing errands. Meditation/qi-gong in the morning.    

No sugar no grains except for pure oats. Loads of veggies. Berries, a  little fruit. Mainly vegetarian protein and fat fish.  100+ grams of fresh broccoli sprouts, avocado, nuts, olive oil, sauerkraut, nuts, potato flour. 4- hour food window.

Prazosin, Melatonin,  EGCG, IP6/Inositol, K2/D3, Ezetimibe, Acarbose, Curcumin, Mg Threonate. 

Standing up all day when working keeps me alert. I have a passion for my job  which demands good mental and physical form including travel in the humid tropics. Hope to keep up at this for a long time  if cancer and aging effects can be kept at bay.

pj1121.bio:
Kaiser Oakland provider
Had issues with what i thought was bph for 1-2 years . GP sent me for urine test, blood work-up etc. but she never added a psa test. Then  I started experiencing dry ejaculation. I was sent to  urology,  blood work markers  all came back fine except for PSA  - it came back 250 tested a second time to be sure it wasn't a lab problem. tested 300   urologist said this was not significant at these levels.
 PSMA Early June , Prostate suv max19. Regional nodes: External iliac 9mm SUV 23 expression 3, Obturator 5mm SUV 3 expression 1, Presacral 10mm SUV 10 expression 2, other presigmoid 4mm SUV 4 expression 1.    Distant nodes: Retroperitoneal several (Example) 6mm 6 mm right para aortic SUV 3 expression 1
 Started Bicalutamide July 1, 2023, lupron July 7.    Biopsy July 13, Gleason score came back as 4+3 (Grade group 3) . 
 1000mg abiraterone, 5 mg prednisone started 8/29/23. went to UCSF for a second opinion. They suggested radiating distant metastisis as well as prostate and pelvic floor. Kaiser MO agreed and Kaiser radiologist agreed to let me do it, though he was dubious of any benefit . 28x imrt a 70 Gy

docbulldog.bio:
My health journey started in June 2006, with a prostatectomy and later radiation. Put  on Eligard and Xgeva which were successful for a number of years.    PSA went up to 16 the summer of 2017 so tried Xtandi for several years, when it failed I tried Zytiga starting 8/21, it failed with psa going to 30. I started chemotherapy, Docetaxel  and have some success with PSA moving down to eight after six sessions. I am continuing on through 10 sessions now. Mets have been minimal and have caused very little pain. 
PSA on the rise 16, started new chemo 05/16/22, Cabazitaxel. 3 infusions but it failed. PSA now at 141 
Started Pluvicto 08/30/22 PSA 308 with little to no pain. Failed the treatment after Dec infusion, psa at 758.
Started more chemo, Docetaxel and Carboplatin 01/30/23, labs aren’t bad, hopeful for some success. PSA dropped to 176
Bone Mets in chest and pelvic areas. Looking for palliative care if new radiation in my area were available. Not a lot of pain, knees and neuropathy are worse.
Had to quit this treatment because blood counts weren’t good, very low platelet count. 
Started Nubeqa late October but PSA 12/4  had risen to 224.
Looks like I’m looking for a new treatment plan when I see my oncologist 12/5.
Am now completing 3 weeks of Lynparza along with Nubeqa, psa has risen with Nubeqa but will have new labs this week after a month on Lynparza.
No longer on Nubeqa and Lynparza. As they were not controlling my PSA. 03/24
I started Carboplatin and Cabazitaxel in April but had to stop for Radiation treatment on a skull met. I will return to the chemotherapy treatment next week. Hoping my platelet count remains safe with these drugs and I get a good drop in my high PSA count.
Forced to stop chemo, blood counts not good. PSA has continued to rise, 736 but am having no pain. 
Cancer center has stopped all treatments. I’m still scheduled for my 3 month Elligard/Xgeva shots.
They have given me 6 months to end this 11 year battle of Stage 4 metastatic PC
June 6, 2006 was the date of my RP at U of Washington Medical Center.

jazj.bio:
PSA 31.8 2/4/2022. 30 cc prostate size (avg to below avg). CT Bone Scan (w/ contrast): NEGATIVE. 3T mpMRI (w/ contrast): POSITIVE - One 2.1cm PIRADS-5 T2 DCE positive, and one 1.3cm PIRADS-4 T2 DCE negative lesion. Macroscopic extracapsular extension, seminal vesicle invasion & lymphadenopathy: NEGATIVE. Biopsy 8/12 standard core locations positive: 8 cores positive (5X 3+3, 2X 3+4, 1X 4+3) Additional 8 lesion targeted cores (4 each lesion). Lesion #1 4/4 cores positive (2X 3+3, 2X 3+4). Lesion #2 all cores benign. Some samples show Cribriform Small architecture. Total 12/20 cores positive, overall Gleason score described as 3+4 by Urologist.  Gleason 4 was 16% *** PMSA PET Scan results: NEGATIVE for capsule evasion. ***  RARP scheduled for 6/1/2022 (University of Washington, Dr. Lin)

Post RARP Pathology: Tumor size 2cm, transition zone (near middle - only 20% cases have tumor in this area). Percent of cancer tissue (20-30%).  Percent of cancer tissue with gleason 4 (10-20% - confirms 16% found in positive core biopsy). Gleason score still 3-4, no upgrade from biopsy results. Seminal Vesicle Invasion: Negative. Extracapular Extension: Negative. Positive Surgical Margins: Negative. Lymph node involvement (14 nodes removed): Negative.  Perineural Invasion: Positive.  Cribriform gland pattern: positive (small size) 

uPSA at 6 weeks post-RARP and every 3 months for 14 months post-RARP reported as < 0.02.  
uPSA at 18 months from < 0.02 to 0.02 (no change of testing clinic, confirmed by second blood draw 4 days later).
uPSA at 22 months 0.02 (Consult with Dr. Amar Kishan at UCLA who believes Salvage RT is not necessary when I reach 0.05 but if I want to do it earlier than later 0.1 would not be premature.  Dr. Lin at UW/Fred Hutch says they don't recommend salvage treatment until 0.2)
uPSA at 26 months 0.03

Other medical/physical data:

BMI hovers around 22.

Moderate high blood pressure and cholesterol (on moderate dose 25mg Losartan and 20mg Simvastatin)

Diet: Flexitarian (mostly about 75% plants/fruits (mostly veggies) and 25% animal (mostly fish/shellfish with small amounts of lean chicken/beef/pork - indulge occasionally (couple times a month) in a burger or steak.)  

Alcohol: Inconsistent. 0-3 servings daily probably averages out to 2 glasses a wine a day per week = 14 servings.  This is typically considered a NO NO for cancer survivors but I decided to live with the risk and try to minimize by sticking to 90% red wine due to potential benefits of the resveratrol. Recent news about alcohol and cancer has me considering trying to get closer to 7 servings a week.

Exercise: Best described as inconsistent: 1-3 X 0.5-1 hour per week (both resistance and cardio) in many cases much higher (from skiing or mountain biking).  Getting more consistent on closer to 3 times a week due to apparent BCR starting.

16-hour fast every day (don't eat breakfast) and take 100mg dihydroberberine 30 min before lunch and dinner (for glucose metabolism and anti-metastatic potential - dihydro form has been shown to have better bioavailability and is equivalent to roughly 500mg+ regular berberine with larger AUC for blood levels.)

D3 60,000 IU weekly Winter 50,000 IU weekly Summer (D3 blood level tests 1-2 times a year have been between 40 and 60 (about right on target.)  Surprising that such high doses are required to get to those levels.

+ K2 MK-7 100 mcg daily and ~5mg MK-4 3 times a day.  Significant data on K2 anti-cancer potential and required to prevent coronary calcium buildup due to the high D3 intake. Note (MK-4 has a very short half life and MK-7 has a very long half life and is converted to MK-4)
+ 1/2 baby aspirin (40 mg) daily for anti-metastatic potential with no significant effect on blood clotting.
+  600 mg Calcium at lunch and 400 mg Magnesium Citrate and 7.5 mg zinc at bed for lack of intake in my diet after 1-month dietary analysis (I don't consume any dairy except an occasional pizza - don't like it.) Note only much higher levels of zinc or insufficiency have been shown to be potentially pro-cancer
+ 3 mg Melatonin in Winter and 5mg Summer for antioxidant-based anti-cancer potential (considering switching to high dose, and or doing low-dose in the morning to increase Mel/Cortisol ratio during daytime but preserve Circadian Rythm by using high does at night?)
+ Pomegranate Extract (Ellagic Acid 2X250mg =500mg) only prior to drinking alcohol due to evidence it reduces alcohol toxicity.

kreg001.bio:
Cleveland region. DRE detected lump summer 2009. Biopsy. Gleason 7(3+4)T2. ADT and IGRT gave nadir of 0.8.  ADT likely produced cognition issues.  My lab notebooks bear witness.  Biochemical recurrence in 2015 and salvage brachytherapy that summer.  Side effect has been stress incontinence. Nadir 1.2. Biochemical recurrence in 2017.  Did not want Lupron Depot And took spironolactone for blood pressure, minimize T, and postpone the inevitable.  
Stopped spiro early March 2020. It is a diuretic and antagonistic to vesicare and made stress incontinence more frequent. Also wanted to bump up my T to help my immune system with Covid 19 rampant in the land. PSA went from 2.7 to 5.4 in two months.  Went to Lupron Depot to lower PSA.  3.4 then 3.7 four months later.  Flucovine PET Jan. 2021 shows seminal vesicare uptake and nowhere else.  Interviewing  medical oncologists with office in Cleveland Western suburbs.  Since I had RT with ADT, then recurrence, then salvage brachytherapy I'm cautious about additional radiation treatments by same group (0 for 2).  Maybe time for a new RO.  New clinic.  Gamma knife?  Proton beam?  Does only hot spot at seminal vesicles suggest it remains confined?  Started bicalutamide following Auximin PET.  Big decrease in PSA. Fractional values.  After 18 months with bicalutamide mono therapy have tingling/numbness in pinky and ring finger of left hand. PSA remains below 0.1. Fingers work fine. Tingling is peripheral neuropathy treated with B12 injections and D vitamins.  July of ‘23 slight uptick in PSA. December ‘23 PSA 0.9. Stopped bicalutamide. Had a UTI which can cause false PSA. Antibiotics for UTI. Feb. ‘24 PSA still 0.9. March of ‘24 PSA 1.1; T=363.  June ‘24 PSA 1.6, T=333.  Appears my Lupron ‘vacation’ is over.   Will likely try more ADT.  Visit Doc July 3. Well, major surgery March 15 2024 due to bowel perforation and sepsis resulting in an ileostomy.  Perforation in same region as colonoscopy observed radiation proctitis and argon laser ablation in ‘20.  Much sedation and 3 month rehab. Received Lupron July ‘24. PSA up to 2.7 in October ‘24. DT 4.8 months. An Ict. ‘24 Gallium PSMA negative except around prostate bed. nmCRPC?  Visited two uro’s neither willing to order a CTC or darolutamide. Lupron Nov 14, 2024. Should keep my T down I suppose. Visiting an RO and also referred to Steve Campbell at Cleveland Clinic. Campbell asked me to see Clinic RO and MO. The MO, Moshe Ornstein, ordered prostate MRI (no spread to adjacent organs or bones) and ctDNA (no accepted markers). He took my case to the tumor board and consensus is no focal options left and time to try Nubeqa wit Lupron. Nubeqa starting 1/9/2025. Feb. 13, 2025 PSA has fallen to 0.12!  Nubeqa doing its job despite concerns that ileostomy may hinder absorption.

EvFC.bio:
Wife of 60 year old man with prostate cancer

- Gleason 9 (4+5) - intraductal, perineural,
- CT scan found the cancer inadvertently Nov 30 2023
- PSA 5.9 December 2023 and PSA 5.97 April 2024.
- MRI and biopsy March 2024 confirmed cancer. Still thought to be localized.
- Talked to surgeon oncologist Apr 5, 2024
- Bone scan April 9, 2024 - no mets
- PSMA scan Apr 29, 2024 - no mets
- Met with radiation oncologist Apr 29, 2024 - Talked to her again May 2, 2024.
- Talked to surgeon again on May 5, 2024.
- Considered radical prostatectomy and GUNS trial - decided on brachytherapy boost plus 6 months ADT on May 10, 2024.
- First Firmagon injection May 17, 2024 - will continue until January 2025
- PSA 1.41 on June 10.
- Brachytherapy surgery on Aug 6, 2024 - 51 seeds implanted. Spacer also inserted.
- EBRT 25 sessions ended Oct 25, 2024.
- PSA Nov 14, 2024 <0.008
- Testosterone Nov 14, 2024 0.4 nmol/L

MPort.bio: Osteoporosis and Polycythemia are chronic conditions. But heart value issues have surfaced recently. oHS due early next year. I am in the pre op anxious time Tring to work out what's best to do.

Debjimmay.bio: I am a female, 70 years old recently diagnosed with Afib. I am on Eliquis but having problems with nosebleeds and other issues. My doctor has recommended that I get the Watchman put in but I am terrified of any kind of surgery so I’m trying to tolerate the Eliquis. I have problems every day irregular heart rate which is being diagnosed as SVCs  and and PVCs. I have them for days/weeks straight day and night. I feel tired and have chest discomfort during these episodes. Then it will go away and I may have normal rhythm but there’s always some sort of your irregular rhythm daily.

Synergiii.bio:
I'm a (single) 54 year male, who following some chest pains a few months ago (Sept. '24)  was referred to hospital to the cardiology department. On my 2nd appointment 27 Nov, I was strongly advised to stay in hospital as a matter of urgency. Was released 8 days later. 

On Friday (13th) had an angiogram at St. Barts Hospital, which found 2 very reduced L ventricles restricting blood flow to my heart. Again, I was strongly advised to stay in hospital and prepare myself for two long stents, or by-pass surgery (given 2 options of surgeon, and robotic surgeon) in the following days.                                                                         
This I could not do. I couldn’t make such a decision at that time, and so giving myself time enough to research and understand what is happening to me, to make such a life-changing decision. 

Btw…I have not felt any different since any of this has been brought to my attention. Then or even now. There has a few moments when I have become short of breath. Though not prolonged, and gone momentarily. 

I now carry a GNT spray in case of angina or prolonged shortness of breath. 

Have a followup appointment at St. Bart's with consultant Surgeon January 8th 2025, and mentally preparing myself for for by pass surgery in the New Year (Jan/Feb) though don't think I will ever be mentally prepared.

aFibber55.bio:
I was diagnosed with AF  2020 when I was 65 during the Covid pandemic and found it  dry hard due to lack face to face contact with specialists and GPs and because both my mother and grandmother suffered from it, had strokes and died of heart failure. That was nearly 25 years ago and I have come to realise that there are more options for treatment now. 
I find the unpredictably and  anticipation of the episodes harder than actually going through them.
I was very symptomatic when diagnosed with near syncope for a few times  and it took me a long time to get used to the medication. Once I did I was doing fairly well with only a few episodes a year, but I still found that my dosage of 2.5 mg Bisoprolol twice a day makes me very sluggish.  Apixaban has made me lose a lot of hair and makes other medical procedures more complicated, but I am grateful.

2024 after two bouts of Covid (might be a red herring) the frequency of episodes has increased and I was more willing to consider the offered ablation. Mostly because I realised that that option would become less viable if I went to permanent AF and if I  was older. I had my ablation only 3 days ago and had a rough episode yesterday with both AF and what looks very much like a flutter, so early days yet. 
This forum has been such a help although I do sometimes feel that I might now know  too much about this horrible condition and certainly more than most GPs and have found that it’s certainly true that nobody likes a know-all.

DevonHubby1.bio:
Joined to support my wife who has paroxysmal AF.

She had suffered it for more than 15 years but multiple surgeries and GPs dismissed it as 'panic attacks'

Attacks became more intrusive to her life in 2018,  and GP finally referred her to the local hospitals cardiology dept.
She attended as outpatient, and between having the ECG and seeing the consultant she went into fast AF. Consultant immediately sent her to A&E where she was admitted with a HR touching 200 BPM. She self reverted on the ward early the next day. Put on Bisoprolol for AF, and Rivoxyban for anti clotting. 

Aug 2019: Admitted to hospital when PAF episode went on for over a weak and had pains in chest. Cardioversion abandoned when it put her in dangerous flutter. Week in hospital trying various combinations of Bisoprolol and Digoxin. AF declared permanent and discharged...she self reverted same day. 

Nov 2019: 3 month follow up removed Digoxin

Dec 2020 : Resting HR dropping regularly to low 40s. GP reduced Bisoprolol to 1.25g. Slight improvement to resting HR.

May 2021: multiple AF episodes since start of year.  GP increases Bisoprolol to 2.5 mg.

April 2023: Went into persistent AF. GP increased Bisoprolol to 5mg and then 7.5 mg. Then changed to atenalol.

May 2023: Saw consultant at NDDH.  Beta blocker changed to Nebivolol 7.5mg.

Dec 2024: Phone consult with AF nurse. Reported shortness of breath. Put on diuretic (Furosemide 40mg). Follow up call in Jan, reported still shortness of breath.  Echo cardiogram ordered and put on heart failure medication (Dapagliflozin 10mg).

Feb 2025: Echo cardiogram performed and showed heart failure with EF of 35%. Referred to heart failure clinic in March.

debsmitch60.bio:
Hello my name is Deb and I have been just a week ago been diagnosed with Hypothyroidism 2015. However I have been struggling for 5 years before that and was told it was because of the Menopause. Had lots of symptoms including weight gain, brain fog, muscle pain and even swallowing problems.   All which made me feel even worse than I have ever felt in my life. 
Update May 2021
I'm still struggling whether it be thyroid related or low cortisol and dhea.  The latter I'm being tested for.  I am beginning to think that I will never get better but not for the want of trying. 

Update 28/01/2022
I was finally diagnosed as having secondary adrenal insufficiency around November 2021 due to long term opiate medication. Been put on hydrocortisone 20mg daily.  
Still feeling really ill.

Update 13/12/2023
Well all I can update is how ill I still feel. 
I am paying private for menopause treatment at Newson Menopause clinic in Stratford upon Avon. 
My symptoms of hypothyroidism and Menopause apparently cross over. 
However nothing is ever plain sailing as it seems I am having trouble absorbing estrogel and different estrogen patches through my skin. 
They don't really know why but think my EDS hypermobility and hypothyroidism and maybe secondary adrenal insufficiency could be the cause. 
Right now I'm frightened as it just feels like I'm slowly dying and often think what's the point. 
I tried to see a private endocrinologist who actually  didn't take me on as he thought I was too complicated. I respected him as he could have just taken  my money. 
He said I needed someone who could deal with thyroid, adrenal and Menopause  hormones. 
I have looked and I just can't find anyone. I'm slowly giving up.

Bunchberry.bio:
January 18, 2025: Since August, I tapered by 2.5 each month until I reached 10. Felt good until I reached 10, when aches and pains started to increase slightly. These increased when I went to 9 mg (in early December). Nothing debilitating, but they are noticeable. Contacted rheumie who said to stay at 9 mg until I saw her in January. We met yesterday, and I reported that aches and pains slightly worse over the last month, so she's put me back at 11 mg, and if all goes well, to start tapering by 1 mg per month. I also realized I've been eating poorly in last couple of months and not taking the time for daily rest and/or meditation, which I had been doing at the start of all this. And that can't help. So going to focus on both those in coming weeks.
August  15, 2024: On advice of rheumie, have gone back up to 17.5 mg daily dose for one full month, as I’ve continued a bit achey and inflamed since dropping to 15 mg. Symptoms have improved.
Later in July 2024: Saw  rheumatologist, as my GP was concerned about a couple of things (weight loss  and relative youth (how great at age 59 to be considered young)). Rheumie ran a few more blood tests and confirmed  PMR diagnosis. Advised to stay at 15 mg until mid-August, and then drop  2.5 every 4 weeks  until I get to 10, at which point I will see her again.
Mid-July 2024: Continued taper with move to 15 mg. Noticed  increase in hip tightness and arm fatigue, which has persisted. Nothing close to the pre-prednisone stiffness, but am taking occasional acetaminophen (Tylenol) for it.
Early July 2024: Started taper, moving to 17.5 mg. First week a bit rocky but then fine. 
June 5, 2024: Until 6 weeks ago, I felt like I was a pretty healthy 60-year old, all things considered. Then bang out of nowhere came hip stiffness and pain; great difficulty in getting up from seated,  out of bed, and leaning over to tie up my shoes; as well as sore arms, stiff neck, and unbendy knees. Plus I realized I had lost my appetite and lost  weight —  not unwelcome, but strange.  Plus I have had a rash around my mouth since February, which I had assumed was triggered  by my new CPAP mask but now wondering if it was part of my  immune system going out of whack.  In early June, got diagnosis of PMR, based on my symptoms,  a good response to trial run of prednisone, and blood test results showing  high inflammatory markers and no indication of RA, lupus, or Lyme.

jackiesj.bio:
MS diagnosed..Heart issues and a lover of animals and people.A strong belief in Jesus privately and appreciate others views which makes  me constantly appreciative of all people and beliefs.I realize you need to update over time ….update life and profile because it changes before you know it.Im a Hoosier at heart but what can I say...I love potatoes so Im a spud for now.I am a clown(C.O.A.I. certified) and became a clown because of diagnosis of MS.I woke up and couldn't move my legs.If you fall in regular clothes there is sometimes pity...if you put a costume on they laugh!Many people had to help accomplish this.I also have been a volunteer at the Humane Society.Spay and Neuter!If I could say what has saved me up until now id chose prayer and many others...plus creatures.I am a proud  mamma and grandma of 7.When I think of love I think of people, creatures in my life. Reading of Jesus, trying to be be like Him as my friend my brother He teaches, others examples of Him help me to get thru some hard times, and happy ones.Not techy here and not a smartphone user...wow does that irritate others....I hope by the time I change this profile again that cures, or at least help for diseases, pain etc are well on their way...Blessings....many! adult kids and 7 grands and animal...
update: covid,  Domestic issues, no social network. found out id had a stroke when CABG was done, willing to help others where i can. old Nurses aid...love my babes and grandbabes so much. Healthunlocked thank you for blessing my life...i am here to give and accept.

TuffNuttoCrack.bio:
In October 2022, I was diagnosed with a rare variant of high volume metastatic prostate cancer. It was so rare that. They weren’t able to find anything on it. Had it not been for receiving a brain MRI two months earlier and one of my legs swelling up due to a crushed ureter. It would have probably been over before it started. When I visited my oncologist two months later, my pelvis and one of my butt cheeks was hurting; they gave me a Degarelix shot, then followed up a month later with a Lupron shot, started me on abiraterone and my first round of Docetaxel. Saturday, a week later after chemo, my wife found me unable to get out of bed on a weekend with a fever of 101 and I had fallen during the night, somehow managing with all my strength to pull myself off the floor. She immediately called an ambulance as my oncologist said a fever could be deadly for a cancer patient. During the trip to ER. my BP was 80/60. My wife was unable to get to  the hospital as she could not leave her mother and did not see me for two days. Upon seeing me she told the supervision, this is not the man she knew. I was at the hospital three or four days. 

Thank God they were able to get me in time, my urologist said another six hours and I wouldn’t have made it. Two days after being discharged I went back into the ER for suspected stroke, was held for observation. one brain MRI. two CT scans. half a dozen neurologists,  and a week after that I went back to ER with severe bleeding resulting from a problematic stint. They were unable to diagnose exactly what was going on. 

Since then I recovered somewhat after flunking chemotherapy. My tumors in my bulky lymph nodes shrunk about 70 percent four months after diagnosis. Ten months after diagnosis, a bone scan and CT scan revealed that my tumors had shrunk some marginally another ten percent and my pelvis spot was less sclerotic 

Without the Lord watching over me and the prayers and support of many, many people,  I would not be here in early 2024, nearly 19 months after my first manifestation of symptoms with my left leg blowing up due to the crushed ureter. Thank you Lord for your mercy and please extend it to my friends I have met here. 

To be continued!
