Paused Venetoclax Sept 2017, and restarted Venetoclax Jan 2018 due to MRD rising to 1%.
Taking 400mg Venetoclax daily, no symptoms, but Jan 2022 my  MRD jumped from 0.3% to 1.3% in 3 months.
Dr. Furman has added Acalabrutinib / Calquence to my daily 400mg of Venetoclax and predicted stopping Venetoclax  in 2022 and continuing Calquence indefinitely.  Having short gastro - diarrhea events for 20-40 minutes 3 times per week on Ven + Calq vs. 3 times per month on Venetoclax mono.  
My  April 2022 MRD test was down to 0.07% (from 1.3% in January 2022) but back up to 0.30% in July.  Showing signs of AIHA, so Dr. Furman stopped Venetoclax July 2022, and restarted Calquence after 2 weeks around a colonoscopy. 
Now over 9 months on Calquence- no side effects (except thinning brittle hair). Gastro issues have resolved, skin rash is much better- have paused Light box UVB treatments. MRD test results varying up and down between 0.07% to 0.30% 
December 2023 the skin rash is back mild, and I had the choice of restarting the lightbox or switching to pirtobrutinib / Japirka - which Dr. Furman suggested emphatically, so I started January 2024

Worriedsis.bio: My brother has been an alcoholic for as long as I can remember. Around ten years ago he was having regular seizures whenever he didn’t drink (during work hours) and was diagnosed with alcohol-induced epilepsy. He hit rock bottom after my Dad died in 2022 and has now been diagnosed with cirrhosis. Over the last two years he’s been in hospital too many times to count for things like acute pancreatitis, enlarged spleen, broken sacrum, hip fracture, malnutrition etc. but he has now decided he no longer wants treatment. He hasn’t been honest about his illness so we’ve no idea where he’s at but he’s still drinking and smoking, looks grey, sleeps a lot, can barely walk. He thinks he has 1.5 years left at best. He lives with my elderly Mum so I’m worried for him but also for her and what she is facing. I’m here to get some advice from people living through a similar scenario.

JohnInTheMiddle.bio:
Father, Husband. And now, Grandfather! High-volume, Stage Four, CSPC w/spinal bone metastasis etc. diagnosed April 2022 because of severe back pain, was otherwise symptom free. PSA initially 1700 (not a typo), then (Oct 2022) .03., then (Dec 2022) <.01. ADT (Firmagon aka Degarelix), ARAT/ARPI (Abiraterone aka Zytiga), Prednisone (steroid, standard adjunct to ARAT) and finished 6 cycles Docetaxel (chemo) Oct '22. Trying (trying!) to exercise (see "myokines"). Low-carb diet. NOT taking anti-oxidants!

Summer 2022 - no more painkillers (hydromorphone). My goal is to put off castration resistance as long as possible. (Previously known as "JHMX" on this forum, before name change.)

Summer 2023 - decided to stay on Firmagon/Degarelix (a GnRH antagonist) rather than switch to ostensibly more convenient Eligard/Lupron (a GnRH agonist).

Spring 2024 - aside from fatigue sort of leading a normal life! Crazy! Need to exercise more. And of course coming up scheduled blood work and scans.

Fall 2024 - same as Spring 2024. Scans and blood work still okay, even good. Fatigue. Returning to exercise which I had fallen down on, coincidentally during 6 months period where I had fractional work. Maybe connected? 😃 

Was trying to understand the safety and benefit of low-dose transdermal estradiol for estrogen recovery. (I have decided not to pursue this because when you dig into it, you learn that there are risks related to amazing hormonal feedback loops and different types of receptors and the whole thing is crazy complicated.)

Coming up on 3 years. Which is at least a year or even a little more than the LE at diagnosis without triplet therapy!

SnowQueenOne.bio: Unexplained collapse Apr 2020. Came round within a few seconds, felt nauseous,  spaced out, tired but didn't call ambulance as Covid-19 was being focused on & was told don't call unless life or death situation. Called the surgery the following morning. Fobbed off by GP. Persisted  the following week as didn't feel well. Eventually referred to Cardiology. Loop recorder implanted July 2020. Picked up SVTs, ectopic beats, small palpitations episodes but nothing that would cause a collapse until October 2021. Started with very strong palpitations which felt "different". Went to get my Patient Assist, started to collapse and things started to go black. Managed to grab something to stop my fall. Felt exactly the same after as my Apr 2020 collapse.  Consultant confirmed Atrial fibrillation picked up on the loop recorder.  Consultant asked my GP to prescribe bisoprolol but they didn't. Other episodes followed resulting feeling spaced out, tiredness etc. GP was asked again to prescribe but nothing materialised.  Eventually got my prescription. Dose was low but unfortunately didn't react too well to it. Various side effects. Further discussion with Consultant and currently waiting to go in for EP study with the view of carrying out an ablation within the next few weeks.

Kaliber.bio:
Diagnosed with widespread stage 4 metastatic prostrate cancer ... in lymph nodes , intrapelvic and bones .. especially thorax, lower spine , pelvis , and long leg bones....   DXed very late , first recommendation of care by my team of doctors , last week of October  2018 , was direct entry to hospice . but I decided upon ADT long shot. . ..... PSA 1400 - 1600 ,  down to PSA  <0.1 by January  2019 ,  65 months in a row undetectable. receiving Xtandi, Lupron for cancer  and Zometa for my bones. Being  treated at Kaiser Fresno by Dr 
Tiffany Seto , oncologist. 
    Concurrent diagnosis of  skeletal wide debilitating metastasis  involved bone joint deterioration and crippling  joint deformations.  Cancer drug  induced diabetes, concurrent history of basal skin cell cancer, cancer drug induced hypertension. 
      October 20, 2024 I went past my 6 year anniversary on ADT . End of October, my oncologist started me on transdermal estrogen patches to try to reduce the enormous and extreme SE load I have from my Lupron Xtandi ADT treatment.

Star_22.bio: A daughter terrified of loosing her mum to this disease x

spencoid2.bio:
Diagnosed with Gleason 9 2013. Had IMRT and Brachytherapy along with ADT for 6 months. Noticed a rise in PSA which went as high as about 110 suggesting stage four August 2020. Started Firmagon and Aberaterone and then had orchiectomy in about October 2021. Imaging showed some bone mets and two lymph nodes which were biopsied and are positive for cancer of prostate origin. Recently I have apparently become castrate resistant since there is radiographic progression and a fairly rapidly doubling of PSA.Recently had a pathological fracture right where the biggest bone met is. Considering LU 177 but need to get in a trial since I have not had chemo at this point and would prefer to not. Have an appointment in about a month with a really good oncologist (not crazy about my current one or his nice but unresponsive staff) and hope he can give me a better plan of action.

Started chemo doxytaxel third infusion in about a week.
Finished chemo and after a couple of months PSA started to rise. Last increase had doubling rate of .9 months.Also had CT and bone scans which show radiographic progression. Have a PSMA pet scan in a few days to determine suitability of Pluvicto. 
Update Sept 1 2024: Since the last update I did three rounds of Pluvicto which was put on hold due to low blood counts. Had a total of 15 sessions of targeted radiation to reduce lesions in hips shoulders and  skull.

Now PSA is climbing at about 2.2 month doubling time and is currently at 146. Have PSMA pet scan scheduled in a couple of weeks and will probably get back on Pluvicto.

In the mean time I had a fall and a "pathological" fracture to femur in two places. Recovery is going to be slow and I am trying to learn how to get around my house and shop and keep busy but getting really bored.

WhiteStripes2024.bio: My Dad was diagnosed with GBM stage 4 in early September 2024. We are currently helping him through palliative care. It's a scary, sad, distressing time, but trying to navigate this with as much hope, positivity and peace as possible.

OvacomeSupport.bio: We are the support team for Ovacome, the UK's ovarian cancer support charity. We support anyone affected by the disease, including family members, those at risk, and healthcare professionals.  Please contact us through direct message through this forum, email support@ovacome.org.uk, or call +44 (0)800 008 7054 Monday-Friday 10am-5pm UK time. We're here to support you, provide information or just for a friendly chat.

Burnout67.bio:
A Mom who supports her adult son who has ADHD ,  ASP and other health concerns with any help he needs with organising,  cleaning, reminders, shopping and appointments.    

I am hoping I gain insight to how HE feels, how HE sees life, what HE thinks, how I can help him in or better yet, help HIM to help himself in ways I probably have not learnt yet. 

I am a worrier and all I wish for him is that he is happy and does not get taken advantage of as he falls under the "Vulnerable Persons"    I know he has had dreams or goals in the past and I am seeing this vanish as time goes by.   I have been working hard to find him some intake/ mentorship/ body-doubling and the kind of supports offered here for people who qualify for Community Living Disability Services..   I am also working with organisations , writing letters to people who might be able to open the doors for others who "fall through the cracks" in the system.

He enjoys seeing me visit but I am struggling with how I do this without wanting to cleanup when I see it as despair and depression all around him, similar to hoarding but able to let his things go....
I worry about after I am not here, what happens..?  Will he become homeless?   

Just enjoying everyone's input and learning as much as I can..👋 
Thank you in advance for any advice and tips you are able to share.

Sher78.bio:
Diagnosed with SLE, APS, MCT,  Sjogrens, Raynauds, Vasculitis, PCOS etc etc in 1994 after having a stroke. Extensive bowel surgery in 1994 due to APS which resulted in a colostomy, then an ileostomy (reversed a year later). Diagnosed with acute psychosis 2011 caused by SLE/APS so now body AND mind chuffed up, but hey, I'm still breathing...just! ;0)   
Recently been diagnosed with Fibromyalgia as well as hypermobility Ehlers-Danlos (cos I'm greedy like that & have decided I don't have enough wrong with me already as it is!) 2022, had Adenomyosis & MCAS added to the mix. 2023, diagnosed with TMD.  
Refuse to live my life in 'Bubble Wrap'.      
My best piece of advice? Learn to 'KNOW' your body.  
Plymouth, Devon.

Bluescarf123.bio:
Supporting and caring for hubby (58) has cirrhosis, decompensated, symptoms confirmed are ascities, varices, heptathic encalopathy, his kidneys failed in ICU, was in ICU 3 Weeks, followed by 3 weeks on ward.  (first diagnosis and hospitalisation 2022). Dec 2022 referred for transplant assessment. Mar 2023 transplant assessment completed and he’s listed- Kings, London. Removed himself from the list due to PTSD.
May 2024 palliative care at home. Refractory Ascites July 2024 drained every 3-4 weeks.

MsMorale.bio: I am here to find helpful information for my dad's battle with stage 4 prostate cancer. He is 75 years old and was diagnosed 2 1/2 years ago.

x_Amy.bio:
I had postpartum psychosis after the birth of my only child in 2014. I have since been diagnosed with OCD and PMDD. 

I am a volunteer peer supporter for APP.

Ruffabug.bio: I am a 78 year old woman who has had PLMD since my first pregnancy  in 1966. It has gradually worsened over the years and I now have it my arms, hands, shoulders and sometimes head on awakening in the mornings. I am now on a Neupro patch 4mg plus a 1 mg Ropinerole. All due to augmentation. The only reason I am on this high dose is because I have terminal cancer with about 6 to 9 months left to live. My neurologist has advised my GP to prescribe Buprenorphine when the symptoms re-occur together with ondansetron for the nausea. I am extremely concerned about the future months in particular the end of my life, the last few weeks which I want to be peaceful without pain obviously, but also without my legs jumping about uncontrollably. I have been on the Health Unlocked forum for several years and have found it very helpful. I have been advised  about what treatment I should seek for the future months and have told my neurologist who took this on board and will hopefully follow it so that I don’t suffer too much at the end.

Denzie.bio:
My stage 4 lung adenocarcinoma was diagnosed in October 2010.  My oncologist said my cancer behaved more like a 3b and so he used the most aggressive treatment for a 3b in the hopes of keeping me alive 10-15 months. That treatment was concurrent chemo radiation with cisplatin and etopicide.  The treatment succeeded better than anyone could have hoped.  Currently I am NED.  

Four years into my survivorship I was diagnosed with stage 1 breast cancer.  Then a couple years ago I was informed I had an aortic aneurysm.

MountainHare1.bio: Sensitive soul that finds anxiety challenging. Loves being outside and being at one with nature. Part time pet portrait and wildlife artist.

Loveispatient23.bio:
Father-in-law diagnosed with PSP October 2023.
Sadly passed away December 2024.
PSP along with Kidney/Liver cancer.

KarmaMaya.bio:
Diagnosed with Hashimotos in 2011. Started with 25mcg Synthroid, over a number of years increased this dose until I settled on 80 mcg Levothyroxine compounded SR with 12 mcg Liothyronine. 

Had thyroid lobectomy in November 2021 and endocrinologist switched me to 80 mcg Tirosint and 5 mcg Cytomel.  I experienced anxiety, heart palipatations and irritability so at first reduced, then spaced out and finally discontinued the Cytomel.

Felt okay on 80 mcg Tirosint, but my TSH was low at .15 so my endocrinolgist reduced my dose to 75 mcg Tirosint. At this dose I felt less energy, cried easily and felt like my cognitive abilities were compromised.

Now, against my doctor's inclination I went back on 80 mcg Tirosint. My energy is fine. I'm not so sad or foggy, BUT I am irritable and easily triggered. I feel like I'm not myself, but am afraid to return to 75 mcg. Is this my only choice? Depressed or Irritable?

MRSYafffle.bio: My mum has been suffering from gradual loss of voice for maybe 5 years. She was officially diagnosed in Oct2020 with PSP and has almost lost all her voice now. She has swallow issues and has had a few falls. Everything is a battle to even get basic help from NHS. I'm juggling work, teenagers and care so feeling frazzled.

BorachioHatpeg.bio: I keep going because that's just how it goes. I might not want to but here I am anyway so now here I go I guess

lgutman.bio:
I am a concerned daughter looking for information. I brought my father into the VA ER on 10/22/22 with escalating back pain, and walked out with a stage 4 prostate cancer diagnosis.  Treatments:
Nov 2022 with Lupron twice a year and continues with this,
Bicalutamide began in Nov 2022 and when PSA rose, was discontinued in September  2023.
PSA began to rise in January 2024 and became more symptomatic in Feb 2024,  and urinary incontinence present. 
Xtandi was discontinued in March 2024 and the patient started Zytiga in March 2024 with 5 mg prednisone twice daily June 2024 dr believes Zytiga is failing, pain is increasing, waiting for one more PSA rise in July to deem it failed. 
PSA tests as follows:
12/27/22: PSA=137->16.17->1.49 (12/27/22) 2/17/23: PSA 0.51 3/30/23: PSA 0.32 5/18/23: PSA 0.32 7/7/23: PSA 2.99 8/7/23: PSA 6.44 9/13/23: PSA 5.37 11/13/23: PSA 0.3  1/16/24: PSA 0.76 3/13/24: PSA 2.47 4/19/2024 PSA 1.46, 5/21/2024 PSA 2.14, 7/01 PSA 3:54
Palliative radiation was completed in 12/22, and again in 3/23. 
Alkaline phosphatase 
7/1/2024: 202 U/L (Hig) 
5/21/2024: 168 U/L (high)
4/19/2024: 161 U/L (high)
3/13/2024: 127 U/L
2/16/2024: 117 U/L
1/16/2024: 95 U/L
11/13/2023: 95 U/L
9/13/2023: 111 U/L
8/7/2023: 121 U/L
7/7/2023: 121 U/L
5/18/2023: 108 U/L
3/30/2023: 108 U/L
2/17/2023: 108 U/L

November 2022 PET Scan:
Extensive osteoblastic/sclerotic osseous metastases involving:
Skull/skull base
Cervical, thoracic, and lumbar spine
Bilateral scapulae
Bilateral ribs
Sternum
Pelvis
Bilateral proximal appendicular skeleton
Representative lesions:
Skull base (4:51, 3:51)
Posterior body of C3 (4:74, 3:74), measuring 1.7 x 1.5 cm
Body of T8 (4:139) with mild compression deformity, mixed lytic/sclerotic changes, measuring up to 4.0 x 3.7 cm
Right lateral sixth rib (4:135), 1.8 x 0.9 cm
Right scapula extending into glenoid (4:87, 3:87), 5.6 x 2.4 cm
Left aspect of sternum (4:133, 3:133), 1.8 x 1.4 cm
Posterior right iliac (4:224, 3:224), 2.0 x 1.0 cm

July 2023 PET Scan:
Mixed response of multiple tracer avid osteoblastic/sclerotic osseous metastases compared to the previous exam:
Decreased tracer avidity in skeletal skull base, clavicles, bilateral ribs, sternum, axial skeleton, shoulder and hip girdles, sacrum and bilateral femoral shafts
e.g. T9 activity decreased from SUV 24.24 to 14.40 over mediastinal blood pool
e.g. Left femoral midshaft lesion decreased from SUV 22.31 to 0.71 over mediastinal blood pool
However, some lesions showed increased activity
e.g. Left costal process of T11 (4/162) increased from SUV 11.28 to 19.06, 17.17 over blood pool

February 2024 PET Scan:
Mixed response of multiple tracer avid lytic/blastic osseous metastases compared to prior exam:
Decreased osteoblastic metastasis involving the left costal process of T11
New tracer avid osteoblastic lesion in superior facet of C3 with SUV max 7.09, 3.76 over hepatic background, possibly representing local inflammatory changes
Similar degree of multifocal tracer avid osteoblastic lesions in the hip girdle and sacrum
Sclerotic foci redemonstrated in the pelvic bones
Left posterior acetabulum (4:265, 3:265), measuring up to 4.0 x 3.5 cm

My dad continues to be mildly anemic and has had several falls.  

Hospice initiated on 7/25/2024
Passed away9/3/2024

Lemonpower.bio:
My father was diagnosed with Advanced Metastatic  Prostate Cancer in 2018. Had RP in 2019. Then Chemo. PSA started rising Dec 2021. Jan 2022 He was put on abiraterone with Prednisone, but PSA dropped for a year, then in 2023 started rising, so he was switched to Dex. PSA more than doubling every 3 months. He's now opted for another round of chemo. He could of had private Pluvicto, but his doctors did not think he was suited to this. Not sure why. He sadly refuses to let us go with him to doctors visits.
My mum has severe dementia.
A best friend has COPD and Glaucoma.
I had a brain tumour removed in Feb 2016 after suffering a Gran Mal and am thankful for every day I can get up and get out of bed.

Dec 2023. Dad's Abiraterone and Pred failing. Dad's PSA creeped up to 10. so told to stop taking them.
Dad referred for more chemo that did not stop the PSA rising
Jan 2024 consultants  referred him to recieve xofigo Radium 223 he was 90 Kilos
March 12 My dad who was in decent health and still farming broke his tibia and fibular and became bedbound. The leg took longer to heal due to state of his bones from chemo and Abiraterone
April 7th Dad met with Radium 223 consultant. Consultant said they would have to postpone Radium until leg was 70% healed.
May leg still not healed.
June dad deteriorated  fast around june 20th could not keep food down, was in a lot of pain ( he has bone mets in ribs and pelvis.)
July 3rd 2023 PSA shot up to 630. No more mention of Xofigo treatment aas dad has lost so much weight and he has been put on palliative care. He is currently now no meds for his MsPCa but is been given oral morphine for pain.

GrillMan.bio: Coping with anxiety and depression for many years. I am an INFJ and HSP, and I tend to isolate a lot. Looking for friends that understand. Grilling, gardening and making music are my solace.

Shams_Vjean.bio:
Diagnosed early in May of 2021 with de novo Stage 4 PCa; metastasized diffusely over skeleton and skull with Gleason scores 9&10 in 10 of 12 cores taken from primary tumor. PSA 9.6

Immediately received a Degarelix ‘loading’ ADT injection followed one month later by Eligard ADT; injections every 6 mos. now.

Began 6 (x 21-day) rounds of Docetaxal chemotherapy infusions early in July of 2021. Started on Zytiga and Prednisone soon after ending the Chemo infusions…..and continuing on  with the Eligard, Zytiga and Prednisone at least until progression occurs.

PSA has been undetectable since late in 2021; and in May of 2022 ALP returned back in normal range following a steady decline from the peak seen at time of Dx.

Bone pain, mostly pelvic, is almost entirely gone. Hot flashes continue to be troublesome, and fatigue has been very difficult to overcome. Some increased neuropathy, experienced during and just after chemotherapy, has subsided somewhat.

Fast forward to 07/2023, 1&1/2 years post last CT scan in 12/2021, and my orthopedic doctor is wanting a pelvic CT scan done to be certain the cancer hasn’t spread further in hip area, where I’ve probably developed pain from pushing my walking a bit too hard too quickly. Scan reveals marked healing/reduction of lesions and no new ones on bones in the pelvic area. Think it’s safe to assume that’s transferable to all the bone lesions across my skeleton and skull.

My last bone density scan in 06/2023 showed my mean bone mineral density continues to be near that for a young adult, without any bone support drugs! Beyond happy to have that at 70yo after 2 years on ADT (Eligard) and nearly as long on Abiraterone and Prednisone daily.

Monitoring blood factors every 6 weeks, as I have elevated risk for liver problems, along with biannual bone density scans, and CT or PET scans as symptoms indicate they are advisable.

PSA very gradually and steadily increasing beginning in Summer of 2023:

Jan 17, 2023=0
May 9, 2023=0.2
Aug 29, 2023=0.4
Dec 19, 2023=0.6
Started Provenge therapy in Dec. 2023


PSMA/PET scan on 03/16/2023 provided the following info:

1. Diffuse tracer activity within the prostate, and intensely tracer avid extensive metastatic osseous disease involving the axial and appendicular skeleton. The tracer uptake in the osseous lesions is more than that of the liver, with the majority of the lesions showing tracer uptake more than that of the parotid glands.

2. No PET-CT evidence of non PSMA expressing metastatic disease.

Theranostics RO at the local cancer center of excellence recommended I start Pluvicto therapy sooner rather than later, despite having no symptoms/pains.

PSA on Apr. 10, 2024=0.8; MO advised discontinuing Zytiga + prednisone prior to starting Pluvicto therapy.

First Pluvicto treatment in mid-April of 2024. Worst side effect in the early days following treatment was constant mild nausea accompanied by significant lower GI pain and other lower GI distresses which I’d compare with having a rough course of antibiotics which wiped out most of my gut bacteria. After 10 days tied to see if regular ingestion of a high-quality yogurt might help and it seemed to work well.

Initially fatigue from Pluvicto was no worse than while on ADT and  Zytiga + prednisone. As treatments progressed the fatigue has intensified, but other than that and some mildly elevated liver enzymes the side effects have been tolerable.

Wanting to keep informed on what has been working well for others in the later stages treatments realm for Advanced PCa..

bookandnaturelover.bio:
Greetings everyone,

I have came to this group in hopes of seeking a safe place to interact with others who many be experiencing similar thoughts and feelings and to feel inspired by others journey on the path to awareness and healing. I have been struggling with mental health since about sixteen, and have been seeking help through professional therapy since to manage.

43creatures.bio: Diagnosed very recently in my 50s  and feel like I am in a second puberty. High functioning and tortured yet happy. In love with consciousness, fascinated by everything, high competence and self-efficacy, can't start anything or keep my room clean, just keep falling further behind. Can't live my dreams and just get by doing my job and my career only while life passes me by, which has become unbearable.

TheOvacomeTeam.bio:
Hello...
We are a UK-wide support charity providing information and support for everyone affected by ovarian cancer.

BedBug.bio: I am a female who is new to this group. I recently had the big 65th birthday. I am here because I have anexity and depression due health issues that have built up over the years. Have had physical abuse as a child and several traumatic events in the past.

katieoxo60.bio: I am of more mature age, like gardening,computing, chat, swimming and have more than one illness which effects my mobility,stamina and normal ability. Children grown up, some grandchildren, no pets. Also have great grandchildren from 12 down over in age.

skiingfiend.bio:
Dx with mHSPCa on Oct 2022 at age 62, with bone and lung mets, initial PSA 250 (10/2022). Treated at BC Cancer - Vancouver Centre. So far otherwise generally fit 5'10" 165lb, active in a wide variety of sports and activities. Retired on receiving the Dx. Married 25 years, wife also retired.

Treatment History:
10/2022 - 12 core biopsy - Gleason 4+5=9
10/2022 - Diagnosed Stage 4 High Risk - High Volume metastatic Prostate Cancer.
                     - Diagnosed with > 5 bone mets in pelvis & spine, lymph nodes and 1 lung met.
                     - Diagnosed with hairline fracture to pelvic hip socket at a met site.
11/2022 - Started monthly Degarelix, started hydromorphine for bone pain
12/2002 - Started Apalutamide, stopped hydromorphone @ end of month
12/2002 - Germline genetic testing, CHEK2 mutation
01/2023 - 15 Fractions Pallative External Beam Radiation Therapy - Prostate, Pelvis and Spine
03/2023 - DEXA Scan - indicates Borderline Osteroporosis
09/2023 - Started 6 mo Prolia for Osteoporosis - Supplement with Calcium, D3, and K2
10/2023 - Blood panel shows slightly elevated Cholesterol
11/2023 - Started 20 mg Atorvastatin
11/2023 - Switched from monthly Degarelix to 4 mo Leuprolide (Eligard)
02/2024 - CT Scan and Liver Biopsy confirm emergence of small cell mets
                        Stopped Apalutamide.
                        Stopped Atorvastatin
                        Switched back to Degarelix.
                        Started chemo for SCCP, carboplatin+etoposide, scheduled 6 cycles.


PSA History:
10/2022 - 255.0
12/2022 -  34.2
01/2023 -   4.5
02/2023 -   1.4
04/2023 -   0.23
07/2023 -   0.12
10/2023 -   0.088       T .20 nmol/L    <= last print on Firmagon
01/2024 -   0.097       T .40 nmol/L    <= 1st print on Eligard
02/2024 -   0.17          T .57 nmol/L    <= 2nd print on Eligard
02/2024 -   0.17          T .30 nmol/L    <= 1st print week after resuming firmagon
03/2024 -   0.18          T <.2 nmol/L    <= 2nd print after 2nd firmagon shot

Other:
10/2022
How cancer was diagnosed: visited PCP for symptoms - trouble urinating and bone pain in pelvis (walking with a limp). Bone pain rapidly progressed so that I could hardly walk, needed a cane and had serious trouble trying to walk upstairs. 
Was on hydromorphone for 6 weeks after treatment started (Degarelix+Apalutamide).

01/2023
Bone pain cleared up and I was fully mobile and active again and pursuing activities like skiing, golf, swimming and hiking.

12/2023
Resurging bone pain at end of Christmas restarted taking hydromorphone for break thru pain. Eligard numbers are within target range but just slightly higher than the last reading on Degarelix - see PSA history above.

01/2024
The switch to Eligard is not going good. In constant pain, recently non-stop abdominal pains that feel like really bad cramps. Going to propose switching back to Firmagon and hope this clears up the bone and abdominal pain that started in mid-december. Checked myself into Emergency to Dx abdominal pain. CT scan discovered cancer has progressed including new bone and liver mets.

02/2024
Switched back to Firmagon.
Bad news - cancer has progressed to Small Cell Carcinoma of the Prostate.
Stopped taking Erleada 1 week before chemo scheduled to start.
Starting chemo ASAP (carboplatin+etoposide).
MO states this marks the progression to Castration Resistance.
Most likely recent pain is related to emergence of SCCP and not Eligard, switching back anyway since I tolerate Firmagon better.

03/2024
2nd chemo cycled delayed 1 week due to low WBC/RBC counts (bone marrow suppression).
2nd chemo cycle uses reduced dose based on reaction and recovery to 1st dose.

HeadInASpin.bio: Started to feel a few pains in Jan 23 and within six weeks I felt like I had been hit by a train. I had gone from swimming around 60 lengths twice a week to being unable to dress myself. Finally got seen by consultant in May 23, was diagnosed sero positive RA and began treatment straight away. Not got meds right just yet but I remain optimistic and look forward to happy times with my grandson and hopefully getting back in the pool soon.

DJB74.bio: I'm  50 years old, live in the midwestern US. I have fibromyalgia,  anxiety and depression. I'm on my two feet around everyone but inside I'm flat on my knees. I'm breathing but dont feel alive. Looking for connection.

Artiquety.bio:
Oesophageal and stomach Adenocarcinoma, 4 rounds of chemoradiotherapy so far …
Ivor Lewis procedure with complications of an added leak 
Pneumothorax in both lungs

Mamabear49_.bio:
It’s taken me a while to get to my bio but better late than never!! 🌸☀️💕 I wasn’t diagnosed until my late 20’s with depression and anxiety, but I had it from early childhood. Lots of emotional abuse in my early years.  I learned a lot along my walk with depression/anxiety- went to many therapists, doctors, and meds. I understand that my illness is not curable but absolutely treatable.  I have realized that treating this illness requires a PLAN —-not just one thing. When my life gets out of whack it usually means I am neglecting areas of my life and I am straying from the plan. Just thought I would share them here with you.
Daily sunshine, exercise/walk, meds, talk therapy, a support system, spiritual life, a purpose, hobbies, journaling, time with friends and most of all self compassion. 
I hope this is of help to someone- keep on walking each day, if today is not good, that’s ok, tomorrow is a brand new one, the slate is clean, and we start again.  We win if we don’t quit!!!

EOLHPC.bio:
Current stuff:
My version of infant onset  lupus: dermatology & rheumatology think this began as the rare form ‘chilblain lupus erythematosus’ & segued in Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) as cutaneous forms of lupus are known to do, given time.  My lupus  is further complicated and relatively more unusual because of my other 3  “primary” conditions: Hypermobile Ehlers Danlos Sydrome (hEDS), Antibody Deficiency Disease (panhypogammaglobulinaemia, a type of Immunodeficiency Disease)  which makes my autoimmunity sero negative, and Diethylstilbestrol Syndrome (DESS)…wild cards include a rare 17 year old chondrosarcoma of the hand, misdiagnosed as OA while it grew like topsy, segueing into malignancy

Relatively  few lupus patients are diagnosed with more than 1 primary illness.  And simultaneous autoimmunity + immunodeficiency diseases are unusual.   My secondary conditions include the usual eg Sjogrens, small vessel vasculitis, small & large fibre peripheral neuropathies inc dysautonomia etc & spinal radiculopathy - these neuropathies combined with simultaneous raynauds+erythromelalgia have segued into scleroderma-like severe Raynaud’s ischemia reperfusion injury of the forefeet..& I’ve segued from AID/PID/CTD-related lifelong chronic intestinal insufficiency into intestinal failure, the rarest of all organ failures + chronic intestinal pseudo obstruction with enteric dysmotility - it ‘s been many years since my GI dysfunction made me give up food.  I’ve been surviving thanks to gastroenterology’s care including prescription lab synthesised predigested amino acids aka Elemental Nutrition & pharmaceuticals preventing bowel obstructions.

My consultants ‘think’ my 5 months daily inutero exposure to the internationally notorious endocrine disrupting artificial oestrogen diethylstilbestrol (DES) probably tipped my genetic predispositions over into all this immune dysfunction.  I am a typical DES Daughter, with characteristic DES internal reproductive organ birth defects, vaginal adenosis, infertility, endometriosis etc and am monitored annually by our Gyn Onc chief by NHS DES protocols inc colposcopy
http://ipfs.io/ipfs/QmXoypizjW3WknFiJnKLwHCnL72vedxjQkDDP1mXWo6uco/wiki/Diethylstilbestrol.html

LoveforAll41.bio:
I started struggling with binge eating after high school, this was the first sign something was wrong. A few years into college I was extremely depressed, had suicidal ideations and sought therapy. I went for a few years and took antidepressants. I was well enough to get married to a wonderful woman, but not well enough to finish school.
I struggle to feel worth something, especially since I was not able to finish school  and don't have a house for my family. We now have three kids.
I do okay sometimes, but for weeks at a time I can be depressed. This is usually eating crap, then not exercising which is my one good coping mechanism, and withdrawing from everyone.
I am working on online school and luckily have mostly been able to hold down a job.

UPDATE 2024: 
I am feeling great. I had a good therapist, did ketamine and ketamine assisted therapy, and read the book Feeling Great by David Burns. Now I don't tie my worth to any accomplishments or "success". I am happy to be alive again, which is so f****** freeing.

RavenFeather.bio:
I am a very healthy, active woman who has aged beautifully.
Life is a balance of success and trauma and I am strong and resilient. In April, 2024, I was admitted to the hospital from ER. Four days later I was discharged with no diagnosis or care plan.  My physical and cognitive abilities were very compromised. After a few weeks, I was able to find a probable diagnosis and work with my PCP to be tested and finally see a neurologist June. I received no treatment other than what I can do myself. Fortunately, I am a mental health therapist in the medical field.  I am a trauma specialist and understand neurological functions better than some. I know my symptoms are not mental illness or imaginary. I have no treatment available where I live but through research I have put together a lifestyle program that is extremely helpful for me. My symptoms are minimal enough most days that I am very busy.

Boy_Mama2018.bio:

I have a son who is 6 years old. About a year ago he was diagnosed with ADHD. We have had some emotional struggles along with retained privative reflexes as well. I would love to connect with people that is going through a similar journey.

I am currently using a daily routine to help me heal and function each day, involving butterfly tapping, mindfulness, deep breathing, reading, studying, working out, eating a strict healthy diet, etc. I am currently processing through Cognitive Processing Therapy (weekly) and a Dialectical Behavior Therapy skills workbook (daily). I intend to experience "integration" so that I may stop responding with aggression, anger, a lack of logic, etc., toward my wife. I look forward to gaining support from similar others to help each other heal.

Aprilbaby24.bio:
I am a 59 year old woman, I was working full time in a very physical job. I began to feel uncomfortable and reached out for answers, a probe, ultrascan, mri and several internal exams and pessary rings. Nothing worked or showed anything to explain the pain. Needless to say, I am on long term sick, tried gabapentin, no good so now taking Duloxetine, and vagifem.
The pain excruciating and no body will acknowledge that it may be nerve pain. I have done my own investigations and pain diary.I don’t know what my future looks like now, what job I can do or how I will survive financially as I live alone.I am now taking Duluxetine which makes very little difference and waiting for them to increase the dose!!!!They don’t want to increase the dose because of side affects and won’t prescribe codine. Next step is therapy and try Pilates and swimming.

Dadof2kids3cats.bio: Parent of 2 young adult women with mental health issues. Currently (August 2024) primarily concerned about older daughter with OCD.  She was first diagnosed with OCD at age 8, but has had long periods with no or minimal symptoms. Her symptoms have also changed over time.  Beginning at the end of 2022 she began having spells where she was fearful that some minor physical discomfort might be an warning of a potentially fatal medical event.  This has recently become markedly worse and she went to an ER 5 times over a two week period.  She is currently hospitalized in acute psych care--her choice with our support--and we are exploring her step-down options.

eclipsetucker.bio: Hi!  I'm Angie and have been battling with weird physical symptoms for 3 1/2 years to Finally get a Functional Neurological Disorder/Functional Movement Disorder diagnosis.  I am now in Cognitive Behavioral Therapy to re-train my brain and Physical Therapy to address the physical side of things and it is going well.  I am done with pitty and negativity and am looking for encouraging peers to move forward with my new life.  I would also like to inform people about FND so that it is accepted and understood.  The most difficult journey was the medical field not understanding and dismissing me as psych or wanting attention.  This made me doubt myself and blame myself.  Now that I have an amazing team of medical providers and therapists, I can finally move forward and be the best me!   I also have chronic migraines and Alpha Gal!  I am a hot mess!!!

JezzaJezza.bio:
My health declined during Covid and I struggled to recover. 

In 2023, I was diagnosed with severe panic attacks, high blood pressure, and high cholesterol, and was prescribed amlodipine and statins. I took immediate action, quitting alcohol and caffeine, and have since lost 17kg (2st 9lbs) through calorie deficit, with a goal to lose another 5kg (11lbs) to reach a healthy BMI of 85kg (13st 5lbs). 

My blood pressure is now consistently around 120-125/77-82, and my GP is very pleased. My cholesterol level has dropped to 3.2 from 8.6, which has also made my GP very happy. I've resumed exercising, now doing fast-paced walks of 10-15 km at a pace of 9 minutes per km, 4-5 times a week. 

After persistent heart diagnosis efforts, a cardiologist suspected atrial fibrillation (AF) and started me on Dronedarone (Multaq). Since then, my AF burden, measured via my Apple Watch Series 8, has been 2% or lower each week.

My GP is excellent and also diagnosed low vitamin D and I take 2 x 800 units per day and also I had low vitamin B12. After a series of 6 B12 shots it seems to be back up at the recommended level and we will review in 3 months.

After some side effects with the amlodipine of ankle swelling and muscle aches I find that taking 100mg of CoQ10 every day has really helped.

Puffins1.bio:
I was diagnosed with a dilated aorta in 2021 at 42mm. On a recent scan it showed 65mm. I am waiting for open heart surgery. I've not been able to have the operation as I also have GCA which has meant being on high dose steroids. Now my steroid dose is low enough, I can have the operation.
My dilemma is that I've been told I can choose where I have this done under the NHS and choose my surgeon.

Strawberrycrisp.bio:
I had over 2 years of chest pain. I have eight hospital admissions with chest pain via ambulance .We have a big family history of stents and a bypasses Which was only found to be needed after angiogram. . So I asked for angiogram over 2 years ago which was rejected.  The pain I got so bad I couldn't get up the stairs, have a shower or walk more than five steps without collapsing with chest pain.  I was told it was reflux and there was nothing wrong with me. 
I booked in with the spire for a private angiogram which was done a week later.  I expected a stent with my symptoms and was absolutely floored when I was told I needed a trip or her bypass.  A week later while I was waiting for an op date, I had a big heart attack and was admitted for my bypass.  I then learnt on my previous eight admissions my blood's indicated  heart attack and I was sent home and nobody can understand why.
I am now 13 weeks post triple bypass.  I can honestly say it has been the worst experience of my Life.  The first 6 weeks were the absolute worst and I thought I was getting a little bit better but now the pain in my sternum just will not go away.  I'm not sure how I should be healing.

Amy2805.bio: Hello I’m Amy I’m 28 years old. For the past 3 years I have suffered from severe palpitations. I was told for many years this was anxiety. Earlier this year I had a really bad attack and finally saw a GP who listened and referred me to a cardiologist. I wore a heart monitor for a week and they picked up SVT and Atrial Fibrallation. This was only confirmed to me on 23rd Oct. I was booked in for an ablation on the 31st October 2018. I came home the following day. I am currently still recovering. Fingers crossed everything works.

Marley7500.bio:

RagdollRagdoll.bio:
Got a DVT in March 2023 leading to pulmonary embolism on my lungs and also discovered AR during hospital visit. Keep getting A fib   Supraventricular Tachycardia, Paroxysmal Atrial Fibrillation.14 day heart monitor results very worrying, this was results and i had been drinking 3 glasses of red wine most nights. Patient had a min HR of 42 bpm, max HR of 171 bpm, and avg HR of 75 bpm.
Predominant underlying rhythm was Sinus Rhythm. Slight P wave morphology
changes were noted. 66 Supraventricular Tachycardia runs occurred, the run with
the fastest interval lasting 6 beats with a max rate of 160 bpm, the longest lasting 6
beats with an avg rate of 120 bpm. Some episodes of Supraventricular Tachycardia
may be possible Atrial Tachycardia with variable block. Atrial Fibrillation/Flutter
occurred (30% burden), ranging from 51-171 bpm (avg of 84 bpm), the longest
lasting 14 hours 49 mins with an avg rate of 82 bpm. Atrial Fibrillation/Flutter was
detected within +/- 45 seconds of symptomatic patient event(s). Isolated SVEs were
frequent (5.1%, 76029), SVE Couplets were rare (<1.0%, 3154), and SVE Triplets
were rare (<1.0%, 673). Isolated VEs were rare (<1.0%, 305), VE Couplets were rare
(<1.0%, 5), and no VE Triplets were present

I have given up the alcohol and am eating very healthy and have recently been put on Flecainide 50g TAD,I am Sotalol 40g and Apixaban 5mg TAD. looking for advice to help

Munchies2021.bio:
My name is Anthony and I'm an alcoholic in recovery.  i also suffer from anxiety, depression, ocd and ptsd.  i have a doctor and take medication much of it for my heart.  3 years ago, I am 53 years old...I had a heart attack had quadruple bypass open heart surgery and a stroke

Considering it all, I am doing fairly well, and my recent journey has been for my oldest child who's 18.  he too suffers from multiple emotional issues and is medicated.  we are on a journey for him, for us... a place where he/we can go, learn and be comfortable with speaking about his or my mental health.

with my medication I couple that with AA Zoom meetings daily.  im hopeful this program can help us both.

gerrerd.bio: My name is Ray and have recently retired.  From the age of 17 I have been troubled with clinical depression and related Anxiety.  So have a good idea of what is going on in my mind and body.  After years of struggle the penny dropped.  The only person that could help me was myself, So I got every self help program and book I could.  Slowly things began to change, for the better.  And this is still going on.  I look for new ideas and words of wisdom every day.  The biggest help in my life came from a man called Dr wayne Dyer.  You can see him on you tube.  I came across Health unblocked just to get some info about insurance.  But  when i read the posts i though I may be able to help someone.  Instead of just myself.  I often thought why I still keep learning more, When i have found enough to last me several life times.  Now I know it is to pass it on to people that need to know it the most.  When they are in very difficult times.  So I decided to try and help people on Healthunlocked  by sharing my journey in life. And to be of service to others, This is now my purpose in life.  Lots of love from Ray.  I would just like to make it very clear  ,  I have no Medical qualifications .  And my comments will be purely on how to cope mentally .  They will be mainly on how to control your thinking process .  This is what i had to do over 46 years to survive,  While coping with Clinical Depression and Anxiety .  Dont believe every thing i say i am in this with you all, and still learning.  So from the age of 17 i did not have a clue who to turn to or what to do,  Suicide was probably the main thought i had, fortunately i did,nt  go down that route . so many young  people do. So if i can stop this happening to just 1 person it will be time well spent on this forum.  The only thing i can do is use my experiences to help them.  Im no expert so dont take my advice as medically  correct, its just how i see it.  Always seek medical help first.  And what ever i say may not be correct for you.  But it has worked for me over 46 years and counting.  Use your own mind check it out first. Because if i told you to jump in a puddle would you no!  You make your own mind up and say no. Your humble servant ray.  Never stop trying, you can believe that.!!!

ALUK_Nurses.bio: Welcome to the Asthma + Lung UK's asthma community forum. The team can be reached on 0300 222 5800 (M-F, 9.15 -5) for more personalised advice.  You can also chat with our asthma nurse team via WhatsApp on 07999 377 775 (M-F, 9.15 5). We are closed for public holidays, Easter break and between Xmas and New Year.

NotAChevy.bio:
I am a 54-year-old individual who, until the pandemic, had not sought professional assistance regarding my mental health. It was during this challenging time that I made the decision to consult a psychiatrist and receive a diagnosis for ADHD.

Throughout my life, I have always sensed that I was different, but my parents did not explore this matter further due to the stigma surrounding ADHD in the 1970s and 1980s. In fact, my high school guidance counselor advised my family and me that attending college would be a waste of money, as I was unlikely to graduate. Contrary to that prediction, I successfully completed a Bachelor of Science degree and subsequently earned a Master of Library and Information Science.

Since my diagnosis, I have dedicated significant time to researching ADHD to better understand myself. I have engaged with numerous books, articles, and videos on the subject. While I continue to face challenges in my daily life, I am much better equipped to manage them now, thanks to my diagnosis, medication, and bi-weekly therapy sessions.

I am eager to share my experiences and learn from others. I would love to hear about what strategies and approaches have been effective for you.

pdpatient.bio:
In 2012, I was reluctantly 🥵🤣diagnosed with Parkinson's. During my long journey, I have learned a lot about myself and Parkinson's. I am here to listen, learn, grow as a transformed person and contribute to the discussion. 

I find this funny:    https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-suffolk-51294545

I am 59 years old and diagnosed with diabetes, high blood pressure and Parkinson's disease. I am was diagnosed with diabetes in 1999 and I was diagnosed with Parkinson's disease in 2012. I have been obese for a substantial period of my life and although I have improved  lot over the past few years with regard to my weight, I still have ways to go. In general, I  would say that I have had general good health. It is my hope, desire and my goal to keep it this way the proactive effort. 

Parkinsons medications have made blood pressure medication unnecessary due to the hypotension caused by the Parkinson meds. Diabetes has been well controlled due to the side effects and absorptive issues with Parkinson meds and I am bno longer obese. Cognition has been intact so far and I am grateful for it. Overall it has been a somewhat rocky journey. Lost my job a year ago in 2022.

AmitLakhani.bio:
I developed Tinnitus in 2023 and been on a long journey.

This journey included many desperate attempts to "fix it" and find the "silver bullet".

The medical community and online forum's put the fear of god in me saying there is "no cure"...which i understand.

However, having gone full circle and embracing the power of mindfulness & meditation....i really feel of all the help i was seeking...this offered me the most relief.

I decided to become a mindfulness teacher / coach and now help myself and others with Mindfulness for Tinnitus.

This is my life's calling...

This is my purpose....

This is my act of service to myself and the world....

MrsSmithdog.bio:
I'm the wife of a severe tinnitus sufferer. It arrived on 7 February 2024 and has never left him. We've tried changes to diet, exercise, meditation, relaxation, sound machines, supplements, hearing aids & CBT...
It's a living hell as he cannot get any relief and is in a very dark place with it all.
We retired early to travel but we've been unable to go anywhere or enjoy anything, which is so sad.

Nusch.bio:
Prostate Cancer Treatment Summary
 * November 2017:
   * Diagnosed with prostate cancer.
   * PSA level: 2.222 ng/mL
   * Gleason Score: 8
 * December 2017:
   * Started Androgen Deprivation Therapy (ADT) with Lupron.
   * Commenced Taxotere chemotherapy.
 * April 2018:
   * Underwent prostatectomy (prostate gland removal) surgery.
 * June 2019:
   * Completed initial course of ADT.
 * Summer 2020:
   * Rising PSA levels detected.
   * PSMA PET scan: Identified one positive lymph node.
 * September 2020:
   * Received Intensity-Modulated Radiation Therapy (IMRT/VMAT) to the affected lymph node.
   * Resumed ADT for 6 months.
 * Summer 2021:
   * Rising PSA levels.
   * PSMA PET scan: No evidence of cancer recurrence.
 * January 2022:
   * New PSMA PET scan showed potential recurrence:
     * In the prostate bed.
     * Two new lymph nodes (size: 2-3 millimeters, SUV peak: 2.5-4.8)
 * March 2022:
   * Received IMRT/VMAT to the prostate bed, the two lymph nodes, and lymphatic drainage areas (25 fractions).
   * Resumed ADT.
 * March 2022:
   * PSA: 1.4 ng/mL
 * April 2022:
   * PSA: 0.1 ng/mL
 * July 2022:
   * PSA: Undetectable (<0.05 ng/mL)
   * Testosterone: <0.1 ng/mL
   * Continued ADT with Lupron injection (3-month cycle)
 * October 2022:
   * PSA: Undetectable
   * Testosterone: 0.12 ng/mL
   * Continued ADT with Lupron injection (3-month cycle)
 * January 2023:
   * PSA: Undetectable
   * Testosterone: 0.1 ng/mL
   * Continued ADT with Lupron injection (3-month cycle)
 * March 2023:
   * PSA: Undetectable
   * Testosterone: 0.1 ng/mL
   * PSMA PET/CT: Full remission
   * Continued ADT with Lupron injection (3-month cycle)
 * May 2023:
   * Diagnosed with Diffuse Large B-cell Lymphoma (DLBCL).
   * Left testicle surgery.
   * Commenced R-CHOP chemotherapy and CNS prophylaxis.
 * August 2023:
   * PSA: Undetectable
   * Testosterone: <0.1 ng/mL
   * Continued ADT with Lupron injection (3-month cycle)
 * October 2023:
   * PSA: Undetectable
   * Testosterone: <0.1 ng/mL
   * Completed current course of ADT with Lupron injection.
   * DLBCL: In complete remission.
 * January 2024:
   * PSA: Undetectable
   * Testosterone: <0.1 ng/mL
   * Discontinued ADT (Lupron).
 * February 2024:
   * Removal of right testicle to reduce DLBCL recurrence risk.
 * April 2024:
   * PSA: Undetectable
   * Testosterone: <0.1 ng/mL
   * PSMA PET/CT: Clean (no evidence of cancer)
   * No further ADT.
 * July 2024:
   * PSA: Undetectable
   * Testosterone: <0.1 ng/mL
   * Continued complete remission.
 * October 2024:
   * PSA: Undetectable
   * Testosterone: <0.1 ng/mL
   * All blood levels improved.
   * Continued complete remission.
 * January 2025:
   * PSA: Undetectable
   * Testosterone: <0.1 ng/mL
   * All blood levels improved.
   * Continued complete remission.

Jasbak22.bio: I'm 53 diagnosed with PV jak2 positive when I was 47 from a random blood test for a swollen toe.

ChannelRunner2.bio:
German-American running in Cologne (mostly) along an artificial channel (see photos...)

Having used the work-from-home time of the pandemic to become fitter, I started the Couch to 5K because I have less time to work out since I have to go back to the office. So, now I am mixing walking to the office with running on 3 other days hoping that'll keep me fit! I also do Pilates with equipment 2-3 per week as strength and flexibility training - Reformer, Wunda Chair, and of course Mat. 

Week 1, run 1: 01 August 2022
Graduated Couch to 5K: 01 October 2022
Completed first 60 minute run: 29 March 2023
Completed first 10K: 14 May 2023
Ungraceful fall: 17 June 2023
Back at 30 minutes: 29 July 2023

Finished a sped up version of Couch to 5K after the knee injury in June 2023, which was helping me get back to running gently, about a month later. So far, my knee hasn't complained!

Tiggy70.bio: I was diagnosed with PMR in August 2020.  I had the classic symptoms of pain in my shoulders and then my hips which developed quickly in just over three weeks until I could barely dress myself.  I had chest and hip X-rays which were normal and blood tests which revealed an ESR of 44.  My Gp immediately put me on a dose of 15mg of Prednisolone.  After about 4 days I felt much better but had difficulty sleeping as I was told to take the Pred at night.   I changed this to a breakfast dose and my sleep improved.   My first Pred reduction was after 3 weeks to 12.5 mg.  Looking back I definitely had a flare on this dose but was told to persevere by the Rheumatology consultant.   After another three weeks I was told to reduce to 10mg.  Again another flare and back up to 12.5.  This has been the way my Pred journey has been.  I quickly realized from the posts on health unlocked that slow and steady is the way to go.  I struggled badly to get below 10mg of Pred but using the DSNS method I made it to 8.5 mg.  My Rheumatologist is insisting I reduce now by .5 mg per month.  I’ve tried twice to get down to 8 but the pain returns.  I am currently on 8mg but experiencing the worst pain since diagnosed in August 2020.  The consultant now wants me to take Methotrexate.  I am really against taking this drug yet.  I have type 2 diabetes and I’m currently on 9 prescription medications including Risedronate which the consultant insists I take and won’t refer me for a Dexascan.  I’m currently in a bad place with this illness and will write a post to hopefully get some advice.  I have read posts every day since Joining the forum in October 2020 and this site has been invaluable to me.

Blackwitch.bio: I'm Blackwitch. I have Rheumatoid Arthritis (?) with Secondary Sjögren’s syndrome, Osteoarthritis, Spinal Stenosis, Severe Degenerative Disc Disease with Rotational Scoliosis and Fibromyalgia. I had back surgery in 2012 for spinal stenosis & had a Coflex spacer put in between L4/5. I had a right knee replacement in September 2015. Just after Christmas 2015 I had emergency surgery to remove a bowel blockage. I had further back surgery in September 2020 for 2 prolapsed discs, to release inflamed nerves & scar tissue from previous surgery. Since then I have had severe fatigue, cannot do any cooking or housework & cannot exercise without being completely exhausted. I’m now a wheelchair user. I was finally diagnosed with ME/Chronic Fatigue Syndrome in November 2021. I was diagnosed with Functional Neurological Disorder in October 2022. I have attended 4 different Pain Clinics but have come to the conclusion that breathing exercises are not the cure I’m looking for. I am at the point of thinking there is someone sticking pins in an effigy of me! We have 13 year old identical triplet grandsons. I am now medically retired and live with my wonderful husband and Greek Harehound, rescue dog from Cyprus (Ada). We recently lost our Golden Retriever and Labradoodle within a few weeks of each other so all still grieving as they were part of the family. Good grief, I don’t believe all this myself.

salamander160.bio:
Hi, I am Adrien, I had encephalitis when I was six years old, it left me paraplegic, visually impaired (my eyes work but my brain doesn't) and with epilepsy (which is fortunately very well controlled). I also have osteoporosis, empty sella syndrome (my pituitary gland is damaged or even missing). I have found out recently that I was diagnosed  with spastic diplegia (cerebral palsy) in 1985 but wasn't told about this until a couple of years ago. Because of my multiple health problems I have to use a wheelchair to get around. I also suffer from sinusitis and have chronic lymphedema and am prone to cellulitis. I have an injury on my left foot; I spilt a pan of boiling water on it, needless to say it is very painful most of the time and is still healing after two and a half years. My toes were amputated in February 2023 and this is now the wound which is still healing. I don't know how long this will take but I just have to deal with it! I am normally very positive and very out going and love to chat to people but the injury is making me feel very down which is not surprising! 

I have been going through a very bad patch the last few years, having lost several family members and close friends including my Father, uncle and brother-in-law. I recently got back in touch with other family members and it has made a big difference to me in a lot of ways. I have had a big fall out in the family but still have contact with my niece which is going very well, we get on ok but we both have multiple health problems so kind of understand one another. 

I live in supported living in Devon, I love having my independence, It is very important to try and do as much for myself while I can! I have my own flat, carers do as much for me as I need them to but prefer to do things for myself if I can. I think it is important for us all to try and do as much for ourselves whilst we can, it is too easy to get in to a situation and have to rely on other people but it is better to stay independent for as long as you can. It really helps with your mental health and confidence, life is hard enough as it is! 

I am totally blind although do see light and dark, my eyes work the brain doesn't. I have noticed recently that my sight has worsened, I have cataract and dry eye, very bright light really hurts me. Having so many health problems it is hard to cope at times but you have to do your best. Some things are much harder to handle and currently the burn and nerve pain are really getting to me especially after a dressing change! I am noticing more bright lights at night time, I believe now that these are focal seizures but need to find out more about them.

As you can see, even though I am dealing with so much, I try hard to stay cheerful and keep myself going, it'll be too easy to let go and give in but I won't!

DaisyTed.bio:
After the birth of my first child in 2011, my Dad (retired GP) noticed I had a goitre and advised me to go to the GP. GP sent me for a scan and I was then referred to an endocrinologist, who explained I had hypothyroidism but due to baby brain I didn’t take much in at the time! I was started on 50mg levothyroxine, which was increased to alternating 75mg/50mg each day. 
Over the past few years I have experienced worsening intestinal issues - bloating, cramps, tummy ache etc. GP tested for coeliac (my mum had it) and came back negative. At my wits end, I tried the Happy Gut diet (vegan, gluten free and low FODMAP) and had immediate improvements, but after a few weeks my hair started falling out and I couldn’t sleep. Got blood test and iron was extremely low. GP also did stool test which detected blood in stools. Had OGD and colonoscopy, had biopsies taken for coeliac (negative), but I was gluten free at the time. Couldn’t understand what was going on, or which way to turn. 

It was not until I started to research into my own health that I even suspected my thyroid issue was causing vitamin deficiencies and also the stomach problems!  Coming onto this forum was a revelation as I was told I had an autoimmune condition (Hashimoto’s). This all made sense, as when I went back on gluten again I experienced joint stiffness and couldn’t work out why, but clearly there was an inflammatory response. I take Floradix daily which helps with my iron level and vitamin D spray. 
I am still on my journey to recovery. I definitely don’t have the energy I feel I should, and particularly struggle around the time of my period. Have cut out gluten and dairy and gut problems and mostly gone.
After thyroid tests in March 2023 showed my TSH was 2.8, I had an fight with my GP to increase my Levothyroxine dose to 75 daily - only a few days on this increased dose and the veil of brain fog has lifted and energy levels much improved. Things dipped when I caught Covid at the end of May and now in September, I am struggling with fatigue and brain fog again. Just got Medichecks results and planning to tackle GP again re Levo increase…

SnowShepherd.bio:
Just look at my list of issues... 

Chronic pain, fatigue, weakness from Autoimmune Disease issues (Fibromyalgia, Rheumatoid Arthritis, high RA Factor) and I can't get the proper treatment to help me be able to be a productive member of society. SSI Disability has been denying me after I had it for mental health for 6 years in 2012 and reapproved for 3 more years, but 5 year incarceration made them discontinue it... now I've new physical issues with my Fibromyalgia and my mental health isn't resolved even though I've been doing years of therapy. I can barely care for myself or get out of bed almost every day. 😢 

I just want to be a productive member of society and have a job I enjoy that makes a positive difference in this 🌎. Where I make enough money to be able to support myself independently and a German Shepherd dog or two! :-/ Maybe find a new life partner to grow old with. I'm 37 years old and haven't had my period for YEARS now, so probably will never have kids at this point either.  

All I ever wanted was to he happy. Happiness is earned and self made though. 

I need unconditional love which I've never had through my life, especially now and in my adult years. I need to be surrounded by understanding, positive, productive, healthy, motivated, caring, awakened people who have similar interests and build me up NOT put me down, insult me, manipulate, take advantage of me, blame me for everything, 24/7. 

Pray for me!

Murdochsmama.bio: 6 years ago my feet began feeling tingly and burning. Now they are completely numb up to my knees. My legs are weak and even with exercise and weights, I cannot get them stronger. I'm wondering if the weakness is a neurological issue. I e had a Laminectomy in my low back but received no relief from that.  The doctor thought that may help with the weak legs. I have no idea how to proceed or where to continue to look for help. Nerve conduction testing is pretty normal. Now when trying to sleep on my side I have burning in one hip and have to stay off of that side. I'm a 52 yr old female. Is anyone else experiencing similar issues?

LukeFitz.bio:
Diagnosed with hashimotos in 2018. Prescribed 50mg of eltroxin. GP reckoned bloods were normal since then, so no change to thyroid treatment. However, I had stubbornly high cholesterol even though my diet was very good. I switched to vegetarian diet. I had spikes of low mood and energy. GP suggested antidepressants, and statins for cholesterol......I decided not to take them as I felt my thyroid condition might be a cause of some of this. 

In January of 2024 my symptoms became so bad that I couldn't get out of bed. Completely exhausted, depressed, and filled with anxiety. 

I went to see a thyroid specialist who tested T3 levels and cortisol with 4 point saliva test. I have phase 1 HPA axis dysfunction, T3 at very bottom of range, and low vitamin levels. 

I have recently started supplements for adrenal support and T3 hormone has been added in addition to the existing T4 I have been taking. This week (29 July) I will start vitamin supplementation.

I have started to feel a little bit better, but still feels like a way to go. 

This community has been my main source of guidance and information. I am so grateful to everyone who has been so kind and helpful to me. 

Thank you, 
Luke

Stratocaster78.bio:
Portland OCD
 
OCD
I'm a 73yo retired physician who's struggled with OCD most of my life. While initially tic like as a child, it has evolved into obsessive thoughts (like trying to figure out what time it would be if I interchanged the hands of a clock, constantly calculating exchange rates for money when I travelled overseas, figuring age differences between myself and someone else, to the month, etc), perfectionism (like cleaning shelves and countertops over and over until it felt right, screwing in a lightbulb until it felt right, often resulting in breaking it, etc.) But more recently small physical actions (like blinking 10 times in a row until it felt even, swallowing in a certain way until it felt right, often leading to drinking many glasses of water which I'd have to diurese the rest of the day, etc.)These are but a few if the myriad of symptoms that I get. It's like my mind sticks to things to keep it occupied. It's like there's a little dictator in my head that tells me what I need to do, and decides whether or not I did it right. 
It has waxed and waned throughout my adulthood, but I've managed to have a successful career and social life. But it sabotages enjoyment and peace of mind. There seems to be no definite triggering obsession other than the stress of aging and retirement, but over the last few months it seems to be getting worse. 
I had traditional therapy as a teenager, before OCD was considered a neuro disorder rather than from dysfunctional past experiences.
I've had OCD targeted therapy including groups from the Anxiety and Panic Treatment Center in Portland, OR, which kind of helped for a while. As far as meds, once I conceded that I needed them, Paxil worked for a while, but had a side effect profile. Lexapro, although promising at first, doesn't seem to help much now. 
I've managed to have a successful career and social life. I'm married and have a 24 yo daughter.
So I'm open to suggestions, and considering starting more focused treatment. Not sure about how ERP would work as my symptoms change continually.







 


Sent from my iPhone

deValentin.bio: I’m interested in ways to treat OCD because as a teenager, I had blasphemous thoughts I couldn’t get rid of and experienced compulsive “tidying up sprees”. As an adult, I tried to understand what was going on in my mind and I became obsessed about that. Also, when I lose something, I can spend an inordinate amount of time (compared to the value of the lost item) trying to find it. I need to "feel complete" again to stop the search, which is not always a realistic expectation. However, thanks to Response Prevention Therapy, things are more under control now.

nicolaal26.bio:
I have been on an endless painful journey for sooooo long. Prior to 2017 I would suffer with heavy bleeding and painful periods that would last weeks. This was treated with a Mirena which was a blessing until we decided to extend our family further. We unfortunately lost our 6th unborn child, which devastated us that much we decided to not try again. 


I had the Mirena reapplied and following 2 attempts it would be displaced, on exploration they discovered fibroids. Treatment was started and I insisted on a hysterectomy which the Gynae team refused and met me half way with having my tubes removed. Following further treatment with a medication an alert was issued on the medication that all patients had to undergo scans of their liver, on receiving this it was discovered I had liver disease. 


In 2019 I was in constant severe pain which resulted in me being bed bound most the month especially around my period. No treatment was working and I had an significant impact in mobility, which has led to me having to use a walking stick now. I was unable to go to work or even care for my children. 


After endless attempts and disappointments, the hospital agreed the hysterectomy, the day before surgery they cancelled it due to my Diabetes. I put in a big complaint over their lack of preparation in ensuring a care plan was created and they failed to discuss with the Diabetes team if they were happy for surgery to go ahead and what the care plan should entail (who were in support of the surgery). I lost all faith with the medical team and asked my GP to refer me to another hospital and to the one I chose. I said I was prepared to start afresh as this team was a better one than the one I was under. Whilst waiting for my first appointment my GP diagnosed me as having Endometriosis as they were confident this was the problem. Following this the Pain clinic finally after 2 years agreed to see me and I have been under them since. 


On my first appointment to the new hospital in 2020 I was advised had I approached them first they would have granted my request of a hysterectomy and not put me through all I went through. This left me angry and upset that I had spent years with a hospital that does not follow the same process. Surgery was planned with a careful planned care plan. The surgery entailed 2 outcomes the hysterectomy and exploring for Endometriosis. Due to complications in surgery they were unable to achieve the second part, had they done this they could have removed my ovaries when seeing them having cysts and Endometriosis on them. 
Shortly after surgery I was suffering sever back pain and had a MRI which they diagnosed me with a herniated lower disc which they feel was caused from the emergency in surgery. 


It has took 4 years of loads of scans for them to now diagnose me with Endometriosis on my ovaries and Poly Cystic Ovaries, with the view that Endometriosis is elsewhere too which explains how severe my pain levels are. Surgery is unfortunately at present not an option due to how high risk I am and I was unable to tolerate HRT treatment as it made my Diabetes worse. The plan now is long term pain management.  Regular pain medication now includes: Paracetamol, Codeine, Amitriptyline, and Pregabalin. When my pain levels increase I take Morphine, Ibuprofen pain patches, TENs therapy and Heat therapy . With pain patches being introduced at present to aid in coming off Codeine and Morphine. 


Despite all this medication my pain levels continue to be on a good day 5/10 and on a bad day 10/10 where I need to take the morphine. I have to carry a pack with pain medication and therapy when I leave the home alongside one for my Diabetes. In an attempt to aid with weight loss and due to being restricted on exercise I was put on Ozempic/Trulicity which initially worked, but it is constantly battling my Gynae problems and I always end up with my weight just stalling rather then increasing or decreasing. 


This journey has been one long, depressing, disappointing, and painful, where my quality of life, mobility, and gaining further health problems has impacted on me greatly.  On receiving the diagnosis I thought I would be overjoyed but it left me with such sadness that there is no process that makes this quicker, less evasive, and humane, especially for many other women that undergo this. 


Whilst my story may seem depressing, I see it as a opportunity to aid others to know that you are not alone. Whilst my mobility is still impacted upon and I can only stand and walk for up to 10 minutes, I am grateful I am able to not be bed bound anymore, I continue to work with physio which is a long term process and have started slowly going swimming. The pain clinic continue to review me and I am on the waiting list for acupuncture. I have found work where I can pick my own hours, days and capacity, to gain my independence and help my emotional wellbeing. 


With technology advancing it is odd that this process does not receive the necessary funding to make this process easier for women. There are consultants trained in this speciality and yet they too take too long to make a decision. Each hospital has a different approach rather then follow one approach so there is continuity and women are not having to research into a hospital in the hope they have a better outcome. By continuing to share our stories hopefully these areas become past hurdles, with many avenues of focused treatment plans.
