Jm954.bio:
I was diagnosed with 11q del, unmutated CLL in 2013 at age 56 in UK when I was working as a NHS Healthcare Scientist in the role of Haematology Services Manager.   This included responsibility for the  Haematology laboratories and Haem-Onc clinical trials including those for CLL.  This background has given me a thorough understanding of all aspects of CLL and other haematological disorders including diagnostics, imaging and treatments.  
 I continue to keep myself up to date with Haematology and CLL in particular by reading and attending conferences.   I have been a patient advocate for several years, working with various charities but particularly CLL Support, the only CLL specific UK charity.  
Through these charities, I work with CLL doctors, NICE and other regulatory bodies trying to influence treatment and information availability with the aim of making a positive impact on the health and lives of CLL patients.  My presence here is another aspect of that work.
Personally,  I had 2 years of reasonable health which I used to try to improve my general fitness.  As FCR was the only option in the UK in 2015,  I opted to take part in the FLAIR study and started treatment on Ibrutinib + Rituximab in October 2015.   My treatment stopped in October 2021 and I planned to enter the STATIC trial as soon as it was open.
In terms of side effects, I developed intermittent joint arthralgia which was very debilitating, weight gain, heartburn and severe hypertension  of 228/74 which resulted in an emergency overnight admission to hospital.   The side effects have diminished overtime and my hypertension is now well controlled on Losartan.   In 2021 I was still MRD positive but in clinical CR after nearly 6 years of ongoing Ibrutinib treatment.  In 6 months of 2021, between Feb and October,  I intentionally lost 105 pounds in weight through a low carbohydrate and high fat diet and felt amazing.
In October 2021 my 6 years of Ibrutinib treatment stopped as per the trial protocol and within days I had tennis ball sized nodes under my arms.  My consultant was understandably concerned that I had developed Richter's and there followed several months of investigations including CT, PET (reported as Richter's), biopsies and finally a node removal.  Throughout I felt mostly  well which indicated more of a post Ibrutinib flare and relapse rather than Richter's and the LN histology showed no Richter's, but an accelerated and very active CLL.  Unlike my pretreatment disease where my lymph count was 400+ this time my disease was all nodal and my lymph count never rose above 6.
I was started on Acalabrutinib and had very little response, it held my disease and my lymph count didn't rise but my LNs didn't reduce.  I opted to try a new, first in human trial, of a BiTE - a bispecific T cell engaging antibody in London.  See here for details.
https://healthunlocked.com/cllsupport/posts/147603669/time-to-take-a-bite-bispecific-t-cell-engagers-bites
https://healthunlocked.com/cllsupport/posts/private/147616512/time-for-a-change-of-direction-for-me
Unfortunately my nodes were growing faster than the treatment could work and my liver enzymes showed that my liver was struggling which was going to make increasing the dose impossible.
I returned to my local consultant and we decided that it was very urgent that I get treated with Venetoclax and Rituximab.  I spent the first two seeks as an in patient because of tumour lysis and I found it very hard to be confined to the ward.  The third week I managed to negotiate as an out patient, visiting my local hospital every day for monitoring. During this third week, now on 100mg of V, I was happy to see that my nodes had started to soften and reduce.  Thankfully the last few ramp ups were all uneventful and I  started the Rituximab on time.  
After 6 months I had a CT and BMB to assess my level of disease.  I still had enlarged nodes and approx 1% CLL cells which was disappointing but, as my consultant said, I had a massive amount of disease. My consultant decided to do some preliminary investigations in case I needed a stem cell transplant so blood was taken for tissue typing and a search of the donor register was undertaken.  I was surprised and upset at this possibility.
In February/March 2023 after almost 12 months of Venetoclax I had a repeat CT and BMB to assess my response again - so called MRD directed therapy.  I still had slightly enlarged nodes and approx 1 n 10,000 cells was a CLL cell.  My Dr rang saying he was pleased with the response and now was the time to do the transplant as I had three 12/12 donors, the best that they could be.   He also said that  if I was still reluctant then he wouldn't pressurise me.  
I said that I would think carefully,  knowing that if I were to have one, it would not be successful if I waited for my CLL to start to relapse.  Also, given my age, any older would also increase the risks of my dying as a result of the procedure.   
After I week, I sent him an email saying I wanted to go ahead with the stem cell transplant and thanking him for being so proactive in looking after me.  The transplant team rang a week later saying that he had chosen the 25 year old male as my  donor and they would now be in touch with him.  My transplant was originally scheduled for May 2023 but I asked for it to be June and the date is coincidentally, precisely 10 years since my diagnosis.   I'm very grateful to my donor and the haematology team for this chance of long term remission.
I went into hospital on 19th June 2023 and had 6 days of intensive chemo followed by my new German stem cells on day 7.  That is officially known as Day 0 and all the days following are Day + n.  The first few weeks post transplant were stormy, complicated by infection, vomiting, tremor and severe mouth ulceration needing morphine.  A change of cyclosporin to tacrolimus had a really positive effect and drastically reduced the vomiting and tremor, my real recovery started at that point. 
By day+ 82, I was feeling so much stronger but easily tired.  The important thing is that my new marrow is working fantastically well and a post transplant CT scan shows that my enlarged lymph nodes are gone.  Just a BMT biopsy in early October 2023 to check how much of the marrow is donor.  If it's more than 95% that will be the best predictor of a long term remission/cure.  
Now Day +183 and my bone marrow results from October only showed 73% donor T cells - not good enough.  However all immunosuppression was stopped and a repeat in March 24 will determine the next course of action.  My Hb is stubbornly low at 80g/l and I often have  tachycardia and shortness of breath which prevents me from doing everything that I want to do.  The anaemia is thought to be multifactorial - ABO mismatched donor, folic acid deficiency (result of months of poor eating) and less than optimal kidney function (from the transplant process).   I just feel like I get tired so easily, otherwise I am very well.
Day +350 showed even less donor T cells at 43% and continued anaemia so EPO injections prescribed and a course of donor lymphocyte infusions to try to increase the donor T cells to the required 95%.  This may induce some GVHD so I've a list of things to be aware of.
A slight uptick in my lymph count and uncertainty about whether I needed more donor T cells meant a bone marrow was needed and I had that in early November 24.  After a few weeks wait the results came back - 99% donor marrow and T cells.  I am officially in remission with the prospect of it being long lasting at last.  Just my fitness to tackle now :)

Sepsur.bio:
Overcame avian flu, strep A, sepsis, septic shock, multiple organ failure, (kidney, heart & lungs)double pneumonia, severe ARDS, hypoxia, I was proned, intubated for 8 wks, on dialysis for 7, whilst being in a 57 day coma. I had a trachy fitted for 2wks, moved onto CPAP, PEEP, nasal prongs & nebuliser. Overcame numerous hospital acquired illnesses including VRE, CMV, MSSA, EBV & glandular fever whilst in ICU. Recovery from acute muscle waste, chronic fatigue, delirium & ICU acquired weakness. Living with PICS & Post Sepsis Syndrome, I remained in ICU for 90 days, I was also diagnosed with Chronic Lymphocytic Leukaemia in April 2016 and finally entered Ibrutinib/Venetoclax ( immunotherapy ) arm of FLAIR trial January 2020 at The Christie, after several neck, chest & lung biopsies following a pleural infusion. Previous steroid treatment flipped me into type 2 diabetes. I am on the super vulnerable register and am presently shielding.


2/7/20 Lumbar puncture, lymph node biopsies carried out after concussion and severe head wound - biopsies revealed Richter Transformation CLL had become  Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma although PET contradicted these findings - phew. Restarted Flair trial with venetoclax ramp up expected to commence 21/07/20. 

Declared in remission Sept 2020. Still in deep remission Aug 2021 - will be ending treatment Jan/Feb 2022
COVID 19 survivor October 2021, aspergillosis, several bouts of pneumonia, secondary Covid infection but still in remission Dec2022

June 25th 2022 to December 30th 2022 - no infections or hospitalisations for the first time in 6yrs

March 2023 - still in remission from V&I arm of flair trial -( pointers -  duplicate trisomy 12 & unmutated IGHV )

Waiting for tests for severity of sinus bradycardia with ventricular block mobitz 2

We form part of the Critical Care Support Network https://www.cc-sn.org

CDreamer.bio:
Diagnosed in 2008 but I knew I had lone AF for much longer.  

Since 2nd ablation in Mar 2014 I have had no episodes of AF until Sept 2016 - had several episodes but with fewer symptoms.  2017-2018 increasing number and severity of symptoms until September 2018 when became too frequent and too severe so decided to go for Pace and Ablate but so far, have only got as far as the Pace bit.  Since PM implanted I have infrequent episodes, few symptoms and feel generally much, much better.  I take no heart meds other than anti-coagulant.

Developed sudden onset symptoms of Myasthenia gravis June 2014, treated with Mycophenolate., Pyridostigamine to control symptoms. Took about 3 years to get Mg under control.  Now still have the odd flare, especially if I have an infection, but generally well and starting to titrate down Mycophenolate.

I am interested in holistic thinking and therapies and the link between perception, mental health and body functioning.

SAMBS.bio:
Investigating my own Health and Genetic History from birth till now! I don't have all of, but have been variously diagnosed with, all I've listed. Much of it in last 3 years and given so many prescribed meds they made me feel worse! So I took my healthcare into my own hands!  You may be surprised at the results,. I don't follow all the communities, just ones that on occasion have had something in common over time, with conditions, procedures and prescribed meds and tests I've undergone here in France. I'm still waiting for any definitive  answers so decided to start medically researching for myself. I thoroughly recommend the following, drugs.com - check out whether the various meds you take for various conditions are compatible or not! 
- check out what your blood test results mean! Labtestsonline
- are your different medications compatible with each other? - drugs.com
Wikipedia - great for information on various conditions! Just put the condition or symptom in your search bar and wiki will be amongst the top ones.
Mayo clinic - NIH - both American sites but very good info.

I will not engage in anything involving Cancer though - I have been tested for it and alcohol, in several tests to see if related, and I don't have it  - the specialists have treatment for that well covered. 
Also, it is a distressing disease/treatment regime for those who do, I was a volunteer helper here in France for an Expat Charity that helps residents and their families here, with information, assistance, translation, hospital visits, fundraising etc. I moved away to a different area  and there is no Branch near, or I would be helping out again. I ha e not been without my own health and living condition problems, since marriage breakup. no matter, we are all here on health Unlocked  to listen to and help each other, as, when and where we can. 

I think of the 3/4 Communities I go to regularly, the Moderators/ Administrators are fantastic, the hours of their days they give up to monitor and respond on their respective communities, along with us mere mortals who are not medical specialists or doctors, but just trying to help other as best we can :-) 

Last but not least - Don't forget, we are ALL individuals, even though we may have the same illness/ condition title, information you find must be used at your own discretion, in the context of being relevant to you - if in doubt Go and See your own Doctor! Wishing you all Health, happiness and  of course, a solution to your queries! 
PS, as if you hadn't guessed, yes I am Half English and Scottish, not so easy learning French now ! 

I enjoy, computing, reading, politics,pot plant gardening  I've semi adopted  twice,  abandoned cats -  Ist was black and currently it's a Tabby - both been deflea'd and wormed, fed and loved, but not allowed inside, don't know if I may have to move again! 
,

SootyB.bio:
I figured it was time to update this!  I'm 32, a full-time NHS podiatrist, have a lovely Mum, a wonderful boyfriend, and 3 cats (who get cuddles whether they want them or not).  I rather suddenly started with pain in my hands and wrists on 13th September 2011 (and it wasn't even a Friday), which gradually, over a period of a few months, became pain in most of my small joints and all of my large ones.  Currently, it is at its worst in my hands, feet, knees, and hips, but my elbows and shoulders twinge every now and then, just to remind me that they're there! 
  
 
  
On top of the pain, there is the fatigue and the overheating, which I know most of you understand only too well.  My boyfriend is very understanding, but we're a right pair, as he has FAP (a condition causing lots of colon polyps and a predisposition to bowel cancer if the colon is not removed, which his has been), and is awaiting a rectal excision in October.  We wouldn't make a healthy body between us, but we're still happy, which is what counts. 
  
 
  
At the last rheumy appointment, I was tentatively diagnosed with fibromyalgia, but he did note some joint swelling in my right hand, so I'm waiting on the bloods to come back so I know what I'm fighting.  And I am fighting ...

No symptoms of any kid.

Im 73 yrs old working lawyer and starting ADT treatment now with Firmagon and Nubeqa. May add chemo.

MO did genetic testing no mutations but still waiting for BRACA test results.

Mascouche.bio:
Prostate cancer Gleason 8 Stage 4 T3-N2-M1. Not sure I properly understand the metastasis situation. Nothing in the bones or visible on the CT scans but considered low volume metastatic because there appears to be some microscopic ones in a lymph node in my abdomen or something like that.

November 2019 my first ever PSA was 79 just because I turned 51. Had no symptom whatsoever. Weighted 210 lbs at the time. 
Another test a couple weeks later my PSA was 80.
Had a biopsy performed in January of 2020 and was diagnosed Gleason 8 (4+4) with all cores positive.
Had a CT Scan and Bone scan in either Dec 2019 or Jan 2020, none showing anything alarming.
January 2020 became keto pescatarian and joined a gym.
Had a T3-MRI in March of 2020. PSA was 108 (might be because of biopsy from January).
March 2020 did a 18-day water fast which ended in April. My PSA in April was of 116 (which I think might have been due to the fast). Weight was down to 190 before the fast and was 170 after my fast.
Had a Pet Scan in April of 2020 which showed some very tiny metastasis outside of the envelope that would be too small to show up on the previous scans. Told they are in abdomen and pelvic region. Nothing on bones, lungs or otherwise. 
April 18 2002 Got a Lupron injection and accepted to get radiation by end of summer.
April 20 2020 My PSA was down to 78. Doctor says Lupron would not act this fast so it is probably a mix of what I am doing and Lupron. (I now believe that it is what the doctor says but also that my previous 116 was higher than it would have otherwise been to begin with because of the biopsy and of the long fast since I've later noticed that my PSA always rises after a water fast for whatever reason).
May 04 2020. PSA down to 20.74 
May 21 2020. PSA down to 1.95
June 9 2020. PSA is 2.48. Weight is 165lbs and it appears to be my new normal weight going forward. 
June 18 2020. PSA is 2.67
July 27 2020. PSA is 2.49. Refused to get another Lupron shot scheduled for August because I had felt horrible on Lupron, could barely hold on to my job with the clouded mind and lack of energy. Also refused to get radiation for fear of getting new cancers or of getting burns that will never heal.
August 17 2020. PSA is 3.17. Feeling better than I have in at least the past 15 years. Weight typically fluctuates between 160 and 165 which is is less than I used to weight even when I was 18 years old (I was 180 at 18).
September 8 2020. PSA is 4.26 Getting worried about the ever rising PSA so my oncologist says that we could try just doing ADT without radiation as some do for life. Since I had a horrible time on Lupron, the doctor wants me to try Casodex 150mg/day.
September 18. PSA rose anyway despite the Casodex 150mg.
September 20. Started the SQ1 program which is basically whole food plant based (WFPB) with lots of green and carrot juice. Stopped Casodex because I could not work due to it making depressed and so tired. Realized later on that in just 10ish days, Casodex had made me lose 5lbs and my weight was down to 160.
September 29 2020. Started a 7-day water fast to try to protect me from radiations from the Bone scan and CT scans that took place on Oct 2 and 6 respectively. Both scans are negatives just like they had been at the beginning of 2020. 
October 20 2020. PSA is 27 which I now believe was due to the water fast but did not know at the time so this got me scared into giving Casodex another shot but with 50mg/day rather than 150mg. 50mg was much more tolerable and I was able to work.
October 23 2020. Began doing Casodex 50mg and began doing RSO (Cannabis oil) and Artemisinin. 
November 12 2020. PSA down to 19.76 which looked promising.
December 1 2020. PSA is up to 25.
December 2 2020. Upped my Casodex dosage to 100mg. Feeling a little worse from it but am managing to work if I take some coffee and if I take some Concerta/Ritalin for concentration. Failed to notice at the time that this new dose of Casodex 100mg was making me lose weight and did not link the occasional shortness of breath to it at the time.
December 10 2020. Feeling like crap, I started a water-fast hoping to clean up my system and feel better. Went from 157 to 148 which is kind of normal during the fast but I hadn't realized the Casodex was messing up my weight as well so I was not regaining any even after the fast was over I kept losing weight. 
December 15 2020. PSA is up to 31.97. That is when I began to make a connection between fasting and PSA.
December 16 2020. Upped my Casodex dose to 150mg. 
December 22 2020. Stopped taking Casodex completely as I felt just about ready to die. Had been sleeping 16+ hours a day and spent the hours awake to simply cry and stressed that I'll lose my job, house, everything and leaving my wife homeless from dying so rapidly.
December 25 2020. Weight is down to 146, I am not getting better at all despite having stopped the Casodex. However I am no longer artificially depressed from the Casodex but I am so out of breath that even making juice is an effort that leaves me panting. 
December 27 2020. Went to the emergency room of the hospital where they confirmed that my issues are not Covid related and that all of my problems are indeed side-effects of Casodex (confusion, word switching, forgetful ness, weight changes, depression, weakness, etc...). All blood work looks good and the X-Rays of my lungs looks as healthy as those I had taken in 2014. So I just need to wait for 4-6 weeks in order for Casodex to be fully out of my system.

January 2021 started Lupron again. 
April 2021 started Abiraterone
May 2021 began radiotherapy in what the doc hopes might be a possible cure based on the stampede study. Getting 38 treatments (87 Gray) to my prostate and lower abdomen/pelvic region which should end on July 13 2021.

March 2022: Began suffering from peripheral neuropathy in my feet. 
May 2022: Followed Nalakrats suggestion of Benfothiamine (B1), R-Lipoic Acide and NAC. The neuropathy is now under control. 

December 02 2022: Received my last Lupron injection

April 25 2023: I have started to get swollen feet everyday from the afternoon until the following morning. Not sure whether this too is neuropathy from radiation or some pre-diabetes from prednisone

***
May 02 2023: Stopped taking Zytiga and began tapering off from prednisone. My treatment has reached its end for now. The waiting game now begins as to whether or not my testosterone will be coming back and once it is back, then waiting to see if the PSA remains at 0.01 or starts to climb.

June 14 2023: I am now completely off Prednisone. The withdrawals were painful so I had to adjust the protocol to taper off more slowly than the pace that my oncologist had recommended. 

July 3 2023: Have begun the keto diet once more and did a 4 day fast (1 dry, 3 water only). That appears to have helped a lot with the swelling of my feet. It should also help me lose the 50lbs or so that I've gained since I began the hormonal treatment 2.5 years ago.

Aug 18 2023: PSA is 0.09, Testosterone is 3.3 nmol/l (95.2 ng/dL), Testosterone FREE is 52 pmol/l, Testosterone BIO is 1.26 nmol/l

Oct 6 2023: PSA is 0.14 (55.56% increase from previous result), Testosterone is 11.3 nmol/l (326.0 ng/dL), Testosterone FREE is 138 pmol/l, Testosterone BIO is 3.49 nmol/l

Dec 5 2023: PSA is 0.22 (57.14% increase from previous result), Testosterone is 10 nmol/l (288.5 ng/dL), Testosterone FREE is 129 pmol/l, Testosterone BIO is 3.34 nmol/l

Feb 6 2023: PSA is 0.39  (77.27% increase from previous result), Testosterone is 9.6 nmol/l (277.0 ng/dL), Testosterone FREE is 141 pmol/l, Testosterone BIO is 3.65 nmol/l

Then on Feb 16, I began taking Ivermectin 12mg once a day, 4 days on, 3 days off.

Apr 16 2024: PSA is 0.90 (130.77% increase from previous result), Testosterone is 10.2 nmol/l (294 ng/dL), Testosterone FREE is 110 pmol/l, Testosterone BIO is 2.85 nmol/l

Then on April 24, I began taking HydroxyChloroquine 200mg 2 times a day.

PSA 2024-05-15 : 1.07 (18.89% * from previous result).  Testosterone: 294

Note that this latest test was only 30 days later, not 60. Still, even if I double it to 37% to mimic the regular span between my test, the growth has been slowed dramatically where it had been in a ever increasing upward trend before that. Sadly I will probably have to cut my experiment short because a bone scan made earlier this month shows one met to the right shoulder blade. That metastasis is probably what was making my PSA rise so quickly before I began taking Ivermecting + HydroxyChloroquine. 

Because of the shoulder blade metastasis, my oncologist wants me on the Orgovix and Xtandi combo and to get radiation to my shoulder blade. I've agreed to try out the drug combo but asked to postpone the radiation as I fear its risk of causing a pulmonary fibrosis and I've never had great lungs (got on and off asthma and bronchitis 2-3 times a year) so I don't want to have more issues breathing. 

I will have another PSA test around June 5 to assess the impact of having taken Ivermectin and HCQ a little longer but after that, even though I have a prescription for both drugs already, I will likely just take Orgovix by itself for a few weeks to assess its side-effects and only then add the Xtandi so that I can see if it adds more SEs or not to what Orgovix does. 

PSA 2024-06-05 : 1.67 (56.07% * from previous result).  It appears that the benefit from IVM or HCQ was short-lived since the rise continued. Testosterone: 398

Began Orgovyx/Relugolix 120mg on 2024-06-07

PSA 2024-06-26: 0.06 Testosterone: 28.9

Added Enzalutamide/Xtandi 160mg on 2024-06-27

Received radiation to right shoulder blade. 27 G over 3 sessions of 9G each on 2024-06-28, 2024-07-02 and 2024-07-04

 PSA 2024-08-06: 0.30  Testosterone: 28.9
 PSA 2024-10-15: 0.50  Testosterone: 34.6
 PSA 2024-11-27: 0.55  Testosterone: 40.38
 PSA 2025-01-08 :0.74  Testosterone: 49.03

Laguy01.bio:
Diagnosed with prostate cancer with Gleason   scale of 8.  I have had consults with my urologist, endocrinologist, radiologist, and the surgeon. The surgeon was the last consult, i am being steered toward radiation,  proton radiation. The surgeon was going to do robotic surgery to remove the prostate but due to  a surgery for small intestine bowl resection( removed around 12 inches). He was concerned about scare tissue from that and hernia surgery/mesh in my abdomen. He was very familiar with the radiation facility and was impressed  with them. He said he had another patient with Gleason 9 he was thinking about steering to the radiation facility.  I have started the hormone therapy two days ago( pills at this time). Waiting on Monday to call radiation facility and have them set up putting in the markers and hydrogel. I also need to get PS MA and MRI. Also was instructed to start eating vegan or close as i can get. Update: I did PSMA scan and caner has moved outside prostate to right lymph  node. Doc. Said Stage 4A. 
Today , Au g14th i got markers install in prostate  and hydrogel. Getting closer to proton therapy. I have an MRI scheduled soon. Started the lupron shots on Aug. 22nd and had lab work done. PSA showed a drop to 1.44 from 4.25. Not sure what this means but sounds good to me. Up date as of Sept. 26th. ..as of today i am on my 8th radiation treatment. I see rad. Doctor every Wednesday. I saw him on Sept. 18th and ask when they were doing more scans or blood work? He said about 3 months after radiation treatment , which would put it into Nov. time frame. I made an appointment with my regular doctor to get flu shot and blood lab work done. The results were very high liver enzymes, AST 136, ALT 306, but my PSA was 0.13
The drugs i am taking are Lupron shot(once every 3 months), Abiraterone 1000mg, prednisone 5 mg, tadalafil 5 mg. The Abiraterone can cause liver damage and i think that is what is got my liver enzymes elevated to 300. I stopped taking it and the prednisone a couple of days ago until i can see the doctor Friday. It aggravates me that i had to go out on my own to have my blood labs run but i am glad i did. I have to be honest and say i have been self medicating with Fenbendazole, 1 gram a day, started Aug 1st. I do not think that is what is pushing liver enzymes up due to the dates taken and test dates, but i am giving it a break as well. More to come.  Up date Oct 29th. Had a 5 day stay in hospital. I caught a bad bacteria due to my  immunity being weak. Lever enzymes is coming down but the antibiotics have slowed the progress. Feeling good but I pee a lot and i can’t hold it. I have the urge i have to go.
But radiation treatment is over and now it is a waiting game till I have more scans done.  
Up date Feb 8th 2025. Still on Lupron shot every 3 months. I go back to see the doctor next Wed. I will talk to him about the once a month shot. I go back to Rad doctor  march 11th for more scans to see where I stand  after radiation.  I feel good. I am trying to eat healthy. I take supplements and Fenben. 
My sex drive is basically zero. I can still get an erection  but my orgasm  is not strong, but happy I can still perform.  I still get up alot at night to pee. March can’t come quick enough. Last check up a couple of days ago, PSA was .06 and testosterone was 10ng.

43, OH 51,  TTC c. 3 years.
Fibroids + male factor + “resistant womb”!

2 chemical, natural pregnancies in ‘23.

First IVF April ‘24: 10 🥚, 3 fertilised > got to blastocyst but none able to be frozen or biopsied for PGTA.

Second IVF May ‘24 on short antogonist protocol again but started day 21, luteal phase, 17 🥚, 6 fertilised and got to blastocyst but only 1 to PGT testing stage. Found a chromosome issue (Trisomy 18) which meant embryo was “incompatible with life”.

Took a break to focus on diet, supplements and resilience before a third, started in Oct ‘24. 🤞🏻

Third IVF Oct ‘24 on short antogonist protocol again but started day 18, in luteal phase again. Lowest numbers yet at 9 🥚 - 5 were mature. 2 were "giant"! so not used, 3 had PICSI and 2 fertilised so a better fertilisation % than before but lowest numbers. 2 got to day 5 but neither went to either freezing or to PGT testing stage. 

Knew this was always a possibility, but heart-broken, skint and so so sad.

May go to Europe for OE if anything different is suggested, otherwise will be DE for us.

I had a prostatectomy in Oct 2020 and now have recurrent prostate cancer identified by rising PSA  as follows; 10th June 20211.0, 1st July 2021 1.6, 30th July 2021 2.8.  PSMA PET scan on 22nd July 2021 showed potential areas of uptake but undefined.  PSMA PET scan on 23rd September 2021 showed an 8mm right internal iliac/posterior pelvic side wall node which has got an SUV of 3.4.  Started Prostap (ADT) in October for 18 months and finished 37 sessions of radiotherapy to the pelvic lymph nodes and prostate base early March 2022. As of March 2024 latest psa result is >0.01 so ok to date. Minor glyncomastia and just been prescribe tamoxifen 20mg.
PSA remained at <0.01 then in April 24 rose to 0.03, May 0.05, June  0.07, August  0.53 and  late Aug 1.1.
PSMA PET scan 15th August 2024, no obvious uptake.
PSA rose to 36 on 29th November 2024.
Consultation with Oncologist with report below..

Metachronous metastatic prostate cancer diagnosed with a PSMA PET scan of 27 November 2024 and whole body MRI of 26 November 2024.  PSA on 28 November 2024 was 36.  LFTs shows normal readings with alkaline phosphatase of 47.  PSMA PET scan and MRI scan shows an increase in size of the previously seen left iliac bone lesion that measures 19mm versus 6mm with DWI signal characteristics in keeping with hypercellular bone marrow lesions/metastatic deposit.  Subtle heterogeneity in the signal characteristics within several ribs is unchanged though on the PET scan the SUV has increased in the left anterior 7th rib and right lateral 8th rib.  Whilst the MRI does not suggest these to be bone metastasis the PET scan report says that these might also represent early bone metastasis.  No other suspicious PSMA avid lesions elsewhere.

Chanelady.bio:
I have suffered from  Rheumatoid Arthritis for many years. 
I have tried several different treatments,  Methotrexate etc.
I did try very hard to continue with the tablets, but all of the different treatments  brought on very bad dizziness,  after only a few days of starting the tablets. 
I also suffer from Bronchiectasis COPD, Asthma, Diebetes, Carpel Tunnel Syndrome, Depression. 
I've tried to find a good Consultant,  but as many of us know,  that's not easy. 
They tell me that because of my COPD, the Consultant will not give me a Jack Inhibitor course of Treatment,  saying that it will lower my Immune system even more. 
I've heard that they are a good way to go and have a good record regarding side effects,  so I was hoping that they would suit me better.
I originally saw  this Consultant on 3 x 5mg steroids a day and after 15 months under his guidance,  he said that he would not change that course of treatment at all, due to  my COPD.
I've now registered with another Doctor and am currently waiting to see her soon. 
I can only hope 🙏  I receive a positive response.

beogradjanin.bio:
DIagnosed MPC in january 2014 at my age of 50 with PSA 150 and bone and limph node mets.  No evidence of cancer cells in 2 prostate biopsies, only the biopsy of bone shows that it is metastatic of PC, but no gleason score, etc.
ADT since then, plus ocasionally different suplements and traditional and alternative medicines during the road, but till now including D3, RSO, Mg, Zometa (not regular lately, due to Covid restrictions in hospitals). Budwig & B17 leatrile plus acupuncture first few years... Vegan diet and ethic last 5 years... Nadir PSA 3,7.  In 2018/2019 docetaxel at PSA 55, after 6 doses PSA went to 5, but steady rise after finishing treatment till 85 in july 2020. Than started Xtandi now the fifth month, PSA went down to 10. During this 7 years only 1 new met of 6th rib was found beside the ones from 2014 (ishiadic, L3 and iliac bones). Pretty good quality of life, despite minor side effects.

Turquoisenona.bio:
In my early 30's I had my first experience with hyperthyroidism (around 2006), diagnosed as Grave's disease.  I took the anti thyroid medication for around half a year and went into remission and was able to stop taking the medication. Around 3 years later it came back and again a repeat of the anti thyroid medication sorted it out relatively quickly. This pattern repeated every 3 years or so until the last time in 2020 when I decided to go for a total thyroidectomy.  Almost instantly I felt different.  My weight started increasing, my energy levels plummeted and I went from being a very happy person to struggling to find the joy in things.  Over the last year or so things have only deteriorated.  I get a lot of neck and shoulder pain, my cholesterol levels have risen and my hba1c is only just outside of the pre diabetes range.  I am ready to take this into my own hands as I want to feel 'me' again.  I am prescribed 100mcg Levothyroxine by my doctor but it isn't quite enough so have been cutting tablets to make it up to around 110mcg daily. I felt greatly improved on this amount but have recently started Armour Thyroid (2 grains daily) to see if this makes a difference.

After trialing Armour and not getting on with taking 2 grains daily (also more would have been needed for optimum results) my private dr has changed me back to Levothyroxine plus 20mcg of T3.

LVMonsoon.bio: I presented with Stage IVb PC in March, 2024, came out of nowhere. I have had a PSA test yearly from 2015, all in the 'envelope' of normal until late 2023, my PSA went from 3.6 to 12. PCP sent me for a CT of my Prostate and it showed quite a mess of Mets. Next stop the Urologist, biopsy, Gleason 8. Finally got an MO that was highly recommend in early April, 2024, PSA now 54. He immediately scheduled me for a PSMA PET scan in mid April, 2024 and it confirmed, as he so subtilty put it, that I had a 'heavy load' (pelvis, right leg, few ribs, some lymph nodes, etc.). He immediately put me on Orgovyx. Two weeks later Nubeqa. Early May, 2024 we had the discussion about Triplet therapy and I had already done some research on it and agreed, so we started the 6 rounds of Taxotere. It was rather rough, but not dibilitating, I was lucky. My PSA started droping quite impressively, from 54, 43, 10, 5, .75, .44, .28 and on my last round in late August, it was down to .15. After the Taxotere, it went down to .1 in early September, .09 in late September, .14 in late October and today, November 27th, it spiked to 1.05 (all along staying on the Orgovyx and Nubeqa). I had already been scheduled for another PSMA PET for early December to see if their were any 'hotspots', but I was not expecting (or hoping) for such a spike in the PSA. My next appointment with my MO is in 8 days, so I'm trying to speculate what's going on. I'm pretty certain there has to be some 'hotspots' going on, so it looks like perhaps the ADT is not quite keeping things 'at bay'. Anyway, any insights or advice would be greatly appreciated. I'm trying not to over-react, but every twitch, tweak or minor discomfort get's be worrying and this big spike in PSA probably has me overthinking this to much. I have just had an appointment with my MO (Dec, 2024) and he is talking about Jevtana and Xofigo.  My recent Guardant 360 test showed I had a mutation that inhibits the Nubeqa from working for me.

Weng888.bio:
My right hand started to tremor on March 23.  On May 23, I met up with my neurologist and he told me it was PD. Since then I have made a huge lifestyle change, incorporating the following routines into my life gradually:
Qigong, Yoga, Meditation, Supplements, Red Light Therapy, Keto Vegetarian Diet, Intermittent Fasting, Brisk Walking, Prolonged Fasting, Coconut Oil, etc.

My goal is to stay off medicine and be as functional as a normal person. I see myself going up stage someday sharing my journey of winning against PD. I live each day with immense gratitude knowing I am supported by my spouse and lovely children. And I would gladly support this PD community by generously sharing what I've learned.

woppaginny.bio:
I'm a 76 year old guy in somewhat decent health. I have had prostate cancer since 2016,  did my own treatments with vitamins and Nutrients. I did not trust the traditional and modern prostate cancer treatments and do not wish to live with all the side effects of those treatments. 

My biopsy came back with 3+4=7 back in 2016. my PSA now is 24. It seems to fluxuate back and forth. Last month it was 18, month before it was 26, month before that it was 17, this month it is 24. I have had bone scans twice every year and at present no sign of matasting anywhere. Last bone scan was October 2022 and came back clean. I have prostate MRI's twice a year, last one was October 2022. Doc says it is still confined to the capsule but there was a swollen lymph note but thats gone now. It is probably gotten outside the prostate but hope not but since there was a swollen lymph note who knows.

I would have tried try the Focal Laser ablation for prostate cancer back in the beginning but insurance did not cover it.  

I was somewhat in control of PSA until I got a kidney stone and had to have it surgically removed and loss control of PSA. Then started Casadex in April 2020 sfter Psa was 119 after the kidney stone, now 24 on Casadex. Started on Casadex April 1, 2021, still on 50mg daily to date. No operations, radiation or chemo to date.

Found out about Fenbendzole and want to learn more about how this can help prostate cancer and possibly cure it. If anyone has been on fenbendazole for prostate cancer and took fenbendazole please let me know about how it has worked for your prostate cancer condition and where you are now since being on fenbendazole. I need to get rid of this disease so I can live a better life but looks luike I'm stuck with it till the end which I hope is 10 or more years away.

Tommyj2.bio:
67 yr old single male with recurrence. Initial Gleason 6..second biopsy Gleason 8. PSA high of 20 when Tx initiated....Treated in 2012 with standard course of EBRT ( don't recall how many grey) and no ADT or "extras"....   Initial PSA of .2 but creeping up over the years to a high now of 5.9... Online calculators put my doubling time at 1.73 yrs. Nuclear Bone Scan negative in April 2019. Planned initially to just let the disease kill me in it's own time but losing my nerve....  Found this group online and will plan future steps using the fine advice and suggestions offered by it's very well informed members.
UPDATE  72yrs
Multiple bone,CT,psma and MRI have not revealed metastatic disease as of 2024…eligard,Zytiga,pred started Oct 2024…..residual cancer detectable in discrete areas of the prostate proper and salvage SBRT recommended by MSKCC…..5 sessions proton SBRT done in Nov 2024
PSA currently undetectable……how to proceed from here to be discussed with MO in very early Jan 2025.

Cold77.bio:
Due to a rough and tumble outdoors life, I have had hip problems for a couple decades. But I have not often gone to the doctor, mostly because I never needed to do so.

The hip pain got bad in my right hip in 2019 but I figured out how to deal with it. Then this year (2024) in February my left hip started bugging me, beginning with my lower back then settling into my hip.  I couldn't fix it so got a steroid shot in the left hip.

In May 2024 getting ready for my newly-retired living status, my general MD ordered blood tests. One was the PSA.

I had not had one of those since December 2017 when the PSA was 1.1 and that seemed no big deal. Since then, I have had no problems with peeing or poking, but then the blood test in May 2024 showed my PSA was 17. 

So then in June 2024 a urologist found a 50 g mass during his manual exam of my prostate.

Foolish me, I put off the Fusion-MRI until September and the biopsy until October.

After getting what felt like a staple gun up the back end, the results came back with Gleason 9 in late October 2024.

Next was the Ga-68 PSMA PET scan which showed a metastatic bone lesion on my left sit bone (maybe the source of referred hip pain?) and one on a lymph node near my tail bone. So only those two metastases were visible.

So, November 1, 2024 the young urologist gave his diagnosis: aggressive stage 4 prostate cancer.

In preparation for stereotactic body radiation therapy (SBRT), more blood work showed my PSA had climbed to 32 on November 5, 2024 over six months (from 17 back in May 2024).

November 6, 2024 my MO shot me with a 30-day dose of leuprolide. Haven't really noticed any side effects.

Then I started the SBRT aimed at the two metastatic lesions on November 14, 2024 and it ended November 20, 2024, with five sessions in there.

I have cut sugar out of my diet and most carbs and feel great except for that nagging back pain and a weird pain in my elbow....

2024 Dec 2 PSA at 3.21 
Why is it not zero after a month on ADT?

MMBJI.bio:
I have allergic asthma, diagnosed aged 4. Also have hay fever, eczema, psoriasis. 3 children all have it all too (apart from psoriasis.)

My asthma was relatively well controlled, I was fit and active. November 2019 I had an attack from which I have yet to recover. 

I now have a breathing pattern disorder, silent reflux and vocal chord disorder in addition to the asthma. 

Life is dominated by allergen avoidance, which is nigh on impossible. 

Also have long COVID- main symptoms are severe fatigue and brain fog.

WinnieThePoo.bio:
63years old, diagnosed March 2018, first thought about symptoms autumn 2017, probably had it at least 10 years.  
I am dissatisfied with the current state of available therapies, and searching for solutions.  Pharma is in the family.  I have a long established interest in probiotics and the microbiome.
In researching hope, I haven't discounted pharma options, although I am aware they are likely to be partial solutions, with very long lead times.  Exanatide and other glp1- receptor agonists are of interest to slow the progression of the disease.  
I participated in a 2 year trial of a monoclonal alpha-synuclein antibody at Toulouse, which means I did not start conventional medication (pramipexole CR 1.05mg) until March 2020.
There seems to be almost universal support for the idea that significant exercise helps (John Peppers website first alerted me to this, but my Carcassone neurologist and Toulouse research neurologist both strongly endorse it, and the NHS web site does likewise).
Stress management and taking an active interest in recovery/therapy also seem universal recommendations.  I am also intrigued by photobiomodulation and believe regular use of a redlight hat is helping.  
However, the more I looked, the more I noticed how much the microbiome was featuring in very recent research papers specifically related to Parkinsons research. I know a bit about the gut brain axis and microbiome generally from my interest in the subject whilst FD of the probiotic company. And I think that area offers the most promise for me taking immediate action whilst I wait for the lumbering mainstream Pharma community to catch up.  And it would appear the microbiome also responds favourably to photobiomodulation.

Hence I think Parkinsons is Poo. And fixing the poo may significantly improve PWP

The major ones were:-
Knee Surgery 
Spinal Stenosis Laminectomy

My Spinal Surgery was initially successful for about  4 months but I’ve since had further extreme pain and after a third MRI Scan was confirmed that it was now worse than the original diagnosis.

Panthers.bio: I have had Afib since 01/25/2012…My treatment consists of two ablations,10 Cardioversions,& medication…Currently I am on Flecainide Acetate 150mg 2x day & Metoprolol Tartrate 150mg 2 x day and a potassium & magnesium supplement daily…. I have tried Tikosyn & Sotalol but both had to be stopped due to the prolonging of my heart QTs…. I can’t take Amiodorone due to having COPD…Dr is talking about a 3rd Ablation….

bluepuddy1.bio:
Atrial fibrillation found by podiatrist and then by doctor.  Suspected blood clot, because my leg was quite swollen, after ultra sound no blood clot was found.  I was prescribed  bisopropol, also Apixaban  plus Lansoprazole plus a diuretic.  Started to have stomach problems, was allowed to stop bisopropol, but stomach problems have continued.  So far I have had an ECG that confirmed AFib,  a 24H ECG and am waiting for an echocardiogram.  Have not had results of 24H ECG. Have stopped diuretic, doctor said I could do this if I wanted and have stopped Lansoprazole. Stomach problems have gone so must also have been due to Lansoprazole.

I’m retired and live with my husband in Sussex, interests are gardening, painting, nature and animals.    We have a British blue cat,

PomegranateKiwi.bio: I am struggling with suicidal ideation’s currently. Looking for support and guidance. I was diagnosed with major depressive disorder and ptsd almost two years ago. I’m currently not able to afford to return to therapy so I’m hoping being here helps.

CessnaPilot.bio: I believe my first recollection of any type of obsessive behavior was in 6th grade with having to make my “5’s” on my math papers perfect after a comment by a teacher that my 5’s looked like S’s.  Then nothing for a few years, then I started checking doors to be sure they were closed or locked in high school. I was diagnosed with Generalized Anxiety Disorder in 1992. Then in 1995, I had a very frightening experience. This is when I think the OCD really took over my life. I finally sought treatment in April or May 1998, when the symptoms become overwhelming and daily life was getting very difficult. I had good success with medication and CBT/ERP treatment. However, I have had many periods of minor (never completely symptom free) living interspersed with periods of severe and debilitating symptoms. I have had periods where I get better and then get slowly worse again overtime, and I’ve had periods where I get a trigger or triggers in a short time which cause great distress until I can get back into treatment and back on medications. My story of OCD has been one of never completely defeating it, rather, periods of more or less symptoms and distress. I tend to view OCD similar to something like an addiction. I don’t ever feel like I’ve been “cured” but rather that I must just fight back when I fail and the anxiety and worry and obsession/compulsion cycle starts again. My worries are often a moving target over the years. As a long time sufferer, I’d love to connect with others with this dreaded disease and hopefully we can collectively help each other improve lives and live a more anxiety free life.

Pastalover14.bio: I have been a long time sufferer of anxiety. I have will have good times for a while and then anxiety acts up again. I struggle with being an over thinker and being in my head too much.

PiMamaRea.bio: I am a new empty nester, mom, sister, Aunt, and recently had a family member pass unexpectedly.  I am dealing with some new feelings about all the changes in my life.

Kokanee1.bio: I am nearly 62 years old and had my first major depression when I was 24. I've had intervals of many years of remission with many accomplishments and achievements but my depression recurs often. I feel the need to be in a support group that focuses on the issue of depression and its symptoms and consequences.

Mgtd.bio:
PSA was 4.8. Sent to Urologist. He did the work up. Biopsy showed unfavorable stage 3. Gleason 7+3. Cancer in 8 out of 9 cores. Pattern 4 was 95%. Bone and CT scan was normal. No PSAM scan. No genetic issues.

Baseline test showed a T of 694 and Dexa scan was fine. 

Chose IMRT 25 sessions to prostrate and whole pelvic area radiation as a precaution. I started Lupron 1 month before radiation and continued for 5 more months. Ended radiation 6/26/2023. I had a SpaceOAR and fiducial markers installed prior to radiation.

My T returned to pre treatment level about 2 or 3 months post ADT. As my T rose my PSA rose also. Initially it was <0.01 and my last PSA on 1/06/2025 was 0.09.

In hindsight I tolerated the ADT and radiation fairly well. Some minor bowel issues and very little SE from the ADT. No residual effects from the radiation. Sex life is normal. 

My radiation was done at my local hospital. I continue to monitor my PSA quarterly. I see my MO quarterly and my RO yearly now. I never have returned to the Urologist. 

Throughout and before my treatment I was a daily gym goer. I do resistance work and walk about 6.5 to 7 miles a day. I do resistance work for 30 minutes 6 days a week. During the winter I ski and snow shoe. I use my Apple Watch to track my daily steps and distance. 

I have a fairly normal diet and eat three meals a day with minimal snacking. Almost no junk food. I eat limited amounts of meat and love veggies and fruit. Eat a fair amount of whole grains, nuts and yogurt. Drink tea and small amount of milk and eat small amounts of eggs.

Bucksnort442544.bio: Spent my entire life thinking anxiety and deppression /panic attacks were not a real thing until I started having them.. Lost an infant son several years before sytoms began.. They began shortly after I contacted covid and while I was sick I was never hopstilized, however it musta been the jumping off point for me because my mental health has been a struggle

Kellybelly143.bio: Im Kelly. I'm joining because Im looking for a place to talk about my struggles with anxiety

Hailstorm155.bio: I spent almost 10 years in active addiction. This march I'll have 3 years clean. Almost a year into my sobriety I found out I was pregnant. I have a beautiful son whom I adore. Postpartum depression hit me hard. When my son was 3 months old my father passed away suddenly. It was too much for me to handle. I honestly don't know how I did it.  Planning a funeral, dealing with depression and grief on top of having a tiny little life completely dependent on you. My sons father was a terrible support through everything. We are working on things. I've found that I've become incredibly lonely and I am still struggling with depression and feeling like I am valuable. I just really need support. I have no one anymore besides my sons father and my son. Everyone is too busy for me.

Broccolihater.bio:
I had Generalized anxiety all my life (unknowingly though) i used to be told that i am just more "sensitive" than others. It was only after a major incident in my life that i had decided to get help and realized that i have a problem and i need to do something to fix it (2022).

I started to work on my confidence and social anxiety but then; just when i had started to somewhat get my personality and life back; i found that i had developed OCD, and it's one of the most debilitating illnesses out there. I was and (to some degree) am still broken about it. Its like i have been given a life sentence; anything can be going around in my life and ocd will always be back there. I think the more heartbreaking realization for me was: 

That things will never be the same for me (or at least ocd makes me feel this way) i know people online who have reached lifetime recovery through treatments and my dream is to achieve that too!

Smhh.bio: I feel I fail in everything.. I think negative all my life I lost chance to live like people to married and have kids.. Feel guilty not lucky. Regret aboy many things worried about many things

Lorayluv7.bio: I was diagnosed with bipolar, anxiety, panic attacks, ADHD and PTSD at the age 35 I've had a pretty good handle on them just looking for more information to have more knowledge to have a better control over my mental emotional and physical state

JFish33.bio:
our son seemed to have a traditional path early on. Walking Spelling writing etc all seemed within expectations. He did have separation issues at pre k 3 / 4 but did not need to get picked up early. He did ask for reassurance often possibly small anxiety ( now in hindsight). No social issues, great at sports, coachable and  great teammate. In 6th/7th grade teachers would say he stares into space and often falls off tasks. We saw some of that at home. Vanderbilt tests inconclusive. This was shortly after covid. Migraines started and he would get sick. Would need dark  sleep and rest. His test for absence seizures was negative. He remained active w sports and gym. Bloodwork and drug tests all normal throughout.  Got him a 504 plan because the official diagnoses was made about 1.5 years ago. An IEP followed  and an enhance support classes in school. He does not find any purpose or value of classes like Jewelry Studio, Biology, history, etc though likes to learn via storytelling and experiences (he did have a few months of remote schooling but Psychologists typically do not recommend nor will write a script.  School and state counselers ( in and out of school) did the best they could but some made it worse by forcing us to take him for an evaluation at the hospital    The hospital looks at us wondering why we are even there (several hundred $$ later). He has tried 3-4 different medications like trazadone etc - some made him to jumpy some too tired  we did start to see positive mood changes. He wants to work and had  two jobs at 15 even w his ADHD and poor time mgmt and executive function.  He rarely has bad mood swings. There is no F u’s or fingers to us. We drive him to gym every night. Not a perfect family but we won’t give up on him. Med wise, Now he won’t take anything though continues to workout and does take some supplements for adhd and focus but does want to speak much about it. He won’t really engage w counsellers  we have tried men, women, more passive to the tougher or more direct. 

He did have one mild concussion about 3 .5 years ago and months later was hit by a slowly moving car ( no issues other than bad scrapes and burns, as far as the hospital could tell at that time). We as a family have had some trauma from a bad car accident where the suv flipped over to grandfathers death and a sudden death of a 48 year old uncle. Also about 4 years ago. He has ups and downs with a girlfriend who also has her own challenges.  (Our older son had bad anxiety for about 2 months at a similar age though with outpatient support was fine and is now away in college without medication.)  Our younger guy tried outpatient 1 day and did not like the plan nor the group. 

I know that was a ton of info but we just don’t know what to do and as you all know, it has taken its toll on everyone.  Although he started sept and most of October getting up and to school w a friend, now barely goes. We can’t get him into a Magnet trade HS here due to grades. He can’t get another good job until 16 the earliest. We don’t know switching schools would help nor if private schools teachers and staffed are trained for all this.  Even w IEP teachers tell us he has poor time mgmt, no focus etc. we know this and expect it, it’s at the core of ADHD. Sadly we know see why this disorder combo is dangerous and why some never finish HS. We now see what may be posturing and some tick type movements. ( may also be reasons why school is not great - BTW no bullying or issues like that). Although he does not follow instructions well , no teacher said there is any disrespect. 
 
 Any suggestions? We can’t physically push  him to school, we don’t want to go back to truancy court ( and judge sees we are doing everything we can) , we see how traditional learning may not work, he does not acknowledge ADHD/ocd so meds, counseling etc are somewhat lacking to cope and manage.

Soulhurts.bio: I've had MDD most of my life & am going into month six of a depressive episode. Medication stopped working & im trying different ones.  Im feeling hopeless

KaitieWithFourEyes.bio: Got diagnosed and it's a hard battle

I work 24 hours a week managing the office at a furniture store. I hope to reduce those hours this year. I have had PMR for 3 1/2 years and have been on a maintenance dosage of 4.5 mg prednisone for about a year. Lately I have been having a lot of pain during the night and nausea during the day.

Rap_Rock.bio: Well, I always had this anxiety problem for as long as I can remember. I tried dealing with it myself but, it almost killed me.  So I decided to get help, I went to therapy don’t help, I tried medication still did not help. I was getting so bad I had to placed In a in-patient treatment, once I got out of the hospital I was feeling good happy. But now after a few weeks I’m back to where I was. JazzyCat730.bio: I am a single, 60 yr old woman, divorced and living alone. Life hasn't always been good to me, but they say you learn from this. I started menopause about 7 yrs ago and dealing with the aging process, which I am realizing is such a different and challenging phase in life.  I work full-time in a job that is fast-paced and stressful. I am renting and on a strict budget. I write poetry and recently started writing again as I'd like to publish a poetry book one day.   I struggle with depression because I am not where I thought I'd be at this stage in life. Yet, I continue to try to explore opportunities that I feel would bring me more happiness.  Not a whole lot of luck with this but still trying and hoping for some change.

NadineCT.bio: I am a single 68 year old that is retired after working as a social worker for over 31 years. I am the mother of adult twins in their 30's and raising a teenage grandson with depression and a rare medical condition. I have had both knees replaced and have 2 cracks in my back, osteoporosis, arthritis and alot of pain in the last year. I am in need of support but when I get depressed (and sometimes for no apparent reason) I will isolate and don't want to connect with anyone. Ever since I have been home full time, I have been lonely and feel unfulfilled. I also feel overwhelmed with the responsibilities that I have. I am in counseling but she has been away for months due to a job transition. I would like for this depression to leave me and sometimes it feels like it never will because I have been working on me emotionally since I was in my late 20's.

Eddy0.bio:
I'm a  Barista currently working in Saudi, "As I sit in apartment on the second bed where I lay my mindset, surrounded by the echoes of my struggles, I can't help but feel the weight of my responsibilities bearing down on me. I've been fighting to make ends meet, working tirelessly to provide for my mother, sister with a young baby and young brother who still schools, but it seems like the odds are stacked against me. Despite my best efforts, the bills keep piling up, and the stress is taking a toll on my mental health.

I feel like I'm drowning in a sea of despair, desperate for a lifeline to cling to. That's when I realize that I need to reach out for help. I start searching for charities and support groups, hoping to find a glimmer of hope in the darkness.

As I share my story with others, I'm met with kindness, compassion, and understanding. Strangers become allies, offering words of encouragement and support. I begin to feel like I'm no longer alone in my struggles.

With each passing day, I find the strength to keep going, fueled by the knowledge that there are people who care. I realize that asking for help is a sign of strength, not weakness. And slowly but surely, the tide begins to turn in my favor.

I find solace in the embrace of charity and emotional support, and my heart begins to heal. I learn to cherish the small victories and find joy in the little things. And though the road ahead is still long and uncertain, I know that I'm not walking it alone.

QuietButBold.bio: Here to educate myself through my own healthcare journey (plus; to share signposts of support and solidarity with other Community Members, as appropriate, along the way).

Huntlab.bio:
2024 was a challenging year , all started in April where I suffered multiple asthma attacks over space of 4 weeks with various A&E attendances , then came July , I felt my asthma was deteriorating and so attended A&E and normal treatment I was not responding too , which escalated to more stronger medication , again not responding too , I was moved to the care of the ICU team (last last thing I remember was being asked if I ever had mechanical intubation before which I hadn’t), then next thing I know was my brother visiting and telling me I have been asleep for 2 weeks on a ventilator as I also had Covid with the asthma attacks, which was a shock , while it took a few days to try to understand what happened, all I had in my head was all the images in my red (from seeing myself die twice to watching my niece drive around the Ferrari race track (which by the way she loved the story ) but sadly did not happen,  in total I have written down around 70 different images of what I truely thought happened but it is hard to realise they didn’t (strangely I can recall these experience in much detail ) , the ICU team explained these thoughts are down to delirium and it would settle , sadly I have another episode late October which again required intubation (only for 2.5 days) ,  it is now 6 months on and I do still get flashbacks / images popping back in my head at random times 
Can anyone give any advice of how they managed these experiences post 6 months after the event ?  I am waiting for a counsellor as they assessed me in December and indicated suffering some PTSD

Milo2011.bio:
- Started fertility journey September 2022 after partner diagnosed with Oligozoospermia.

- Referred for fertility treatment in Jan 2023, not entitled to NHS funding.

- First private ICSI cycle March 2023.

- Polyp found in endometrium on day 9 scan which looked like a mishap by the clinic as it wasn’t captured on the initial scan.

- Continued stimulation and retrieved 4 eggs, 3 fertilised, 2 blastocysts.

- Blastocysts frozen while operating on the polyp.

- Resumed treatment Aug 2023 with double FET, transferred 13th September.

- BFN 27th September.

- DE cycle December 2024 … 4 out of 6 eggs survived the thaw… only one fertilised… zero made it to day 5 … due for Male fertility investigation with a MF specialist before going for another round

Chinkoflight.bio:
Out of the blue severe stroke, right side full paralysis, some sight loss and speech loss. Blue light into hospital and after tests/scans thrombolised.  In the next 24 hours most symptoms retreated! Miracle because the prognosis was poor on arrival in hospital.  I was away from home and I feel the NHS has not managed me moving back to my local hospital/GP.  Seemingly very slow to respond.  12+ weeks wait for ECG, 4weeks wait for a telephone call from the local stroke team.  Medication not reviewed by GP. No follow up to blood screening. So feeling very isolated at the moment.
Fast forward 11 months and my 71st year has been medically the most eventful.  Moving on from the stroke, a dodgy gallbladder and gallstones was found in routine observations, keyhole op went wrong and full abdominal surgery followed with a longer convalescence in November.  And now in February 23 had an implanted heart monitor but although sore is not stopping activity.
But positively I found C25K, started running in April 2022 a month after my stroke and have been progressing ever since. Working towards an anniversary run weekend 11/12 March.  Mental health totally improved from above initial entry because of running.
Parkrun 1.47kms 27/1/24 syncope , paramedic to A&E and marked my LINQ ILR when I came round. Ventricular tachycardia event found. Still in hospital pending investigations to determine cause. Echocardiogram and angiogram all clear with EF 65%.  Waiting for Cardio MRI in specialist unit.  MRI showed a scar on my left ventricle, unable to identify a cause for this, but it does explain my LVT and the need for an ICD.  Unfortunately as is normal for me, nothing is straightforward and a lead on my ICD displaced on day one causing me to have to go through the experience again 7 weeks later for a lead revision. However , now nearing the end of May 2024 and everything seems settled. Check up in two weeks!

Slidingdoors99.bio:
I went into AFib suddenly last month.
I was in AFib for six months and very symptomatic. I was only not aware of my heart’s erratic beating and quivering when I was asleep!
My electric cardioversion worked, but only for three days.
I was eventually put on amiodarone but only for six weeks as it was effecting my thyroid, pancreas and kidneys.
It did work though -despite being such a toxic drug and I have been in NSR for nearly four months now.
Amiodarone can stay in your cells for six months or more and so I am concerned that this may be the only reason that I’m still in NSR….
I am awaiting a call from a Bristol hospital about having an ablation.

Aquaharmony.bio: A long journey on the NHS to identify fertility issues were likely caused by fibroids after raising concerns with my doctor that my very heavy periods were causing me alot of problems and I was concerned this was why I wasn't getting pregnant. A year and a half on during the pandemic managed to get the NHS to refer me to a gynaecologist who referred me to a gynaecologist who is a fertility expert. We went through tests and found out we both had some potential fertility issues but my AMH levels were good for my age (40 by this point). Got put on the waiting list and opted to do a privately funded round of ivf while waiting for the surgery. Did one round of ivf which I found emotionally tougher than I expected managed to get 6 eggs 4 fertilised using ICSI and two made it to the pronuclear stage and were frozen. About 7 months from the referral I had an open myomectomy and I have been advised I can start trying again after 3 months.

lowtech.bio:

CKrissie.bio: Been dealing with depression, my whole life. I have high anxiety, low self-esteem. I am a perfectionist, trying not to be. I am trying to pick myself up and make myself stronger. Inertia does that, as with everything I do, I find it really difficult, stressful, overwhelming and scary, yet once done, so proud of myself for achieving even in the simplest thing these days. Now have Class B Pugh score, and am absolutely terrified. Not had a drink for 2 weeks, joined gym today, and am researching the best diet for cirrhosis. I'm so scared.

foxkennedy21.bio:
I am 48 years old and suffer from i.b.s c, I think.  I was first suspected to have i.b.s in 2005/6 so have had 8 years of this!  I am very bored of being told the same thing so just now make the rules up as I go along! I have since discovered I have coeliac disease and not really IBS. I struggle with my diet since finding out I have allergies on top!
On top of this I was told I had oral allergy syndrome and so my diet is even worse my bowel is suffering more. I am now 50.

Ksxo.bio:
I had suffered with pains and sleep for many years it started when I was around 12 my mum first took me to the doctors about some of the things I where dealing with sickness feeling faint and other things that we thought where because of my menstrual cycle as it was very erratic and still is. They said there wasn’t anything they could do and put it down to growing pains. I started going back to the doctors at 18 and after many checks and other illnesses where ruled out I was referred to rheumatology and was diagnose with fibromyalgia and joint hyper mobility. 

I am still learning about the chronic illness and trying to change certain aspects in my life I’m very open to learning new coping mechanisms and welcome any advice.

candyapplegrey.bio:
Was finally diagnosed with endometrioid and clear cell carcinoma in womb in June 2020, having originally presented with symptoms in 2017, then again in 2019, hysterectomy + every other related bit taken out in July 2020, now having chemo (carboplatin/paclitaxel). Am also a person. Being treated at Guy's Hospital. Vlog is at: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vq5BhkLXcyI. After 1st recurrence (self-diagnosed), went alternative as below.

Was taking a huge number of things between 2021 and 2024, mainly from the Joe Tippens Protocol. There are a lot of scam sites related to this so beware. Started this after a recurrence hit me barely three months after given all clear.

CBD oil
liquid zeolite
turmeric/curcumin
sodium bicarb
melatonin (10mg x 2 – have to get it from US)
fenbendazole (as panacur c) (being used in trials in US)
zinc
vitamin d3
folic acid
low-dose aspirin
high dose vit c
b complex
apple cider vinegar

but that was too much to remember and too expensive so now I don't take the CBD oil, liquid zeolite, turmeric/curcumin but have added:
ivermectin (horse dewormer) – this has had success in OC in non-humans although not my type (clear cell + endometrioid)
tudca (to counteract any effect the above has on the liver).

My cancer is back but only after I'd stopped taking much of the above because I'd been cancer-free for three years. I don't know if giving up the alternative meds allowed it to return or if it would have anyway but oncologist seems to think I am already past my sell-by date. I am upping my doses as per Dr Mysister's prescription  to try to stall growth of new lesion.

Was offered another operation (4 hour+) with gamut of attendant risks and more of a similar chemo cocktail and did not want either. Eventually, after putting treatment off for a while, asked re targeted RT as lesion is small and on liver. Now had that (2025) and waiting scan.

Spud-u-Like1982.bio:
Hi everyone,
I'm a 41 year old man and I have a history of mental health conditions.  I have diagnosed OCD, stress and anxiety.
I am currently in the process of being diagnosed with ADHD (more ADD) and I am having to go privately for this diagnosis, as the NHS referral I provided came back negative, despite the fact no one interviewed or met me.  They just came to that conclusion via old school reports.

I have worked all my adult life and I went off long term sick in November 2022 and was subsequently sacked in May 2023 and I've been unemployed ever since.  

Like I said, I have just started private assessments and the doctor I've seen this far has noted potential ADHD and Autism.  The latter has come as a bit of a shock, but my partner determined some time ago that I might be afflicted with that. 
For me that particular autism is to do with senses - seeing and reacting to things most people don't.  I'm very empathetic and emotional, but I do see patterns everywhere, patterns that affect me and I very much hyperfocus on things.  I believe the ADD causes erratic hyperfocus and hobbies, where they chop and change without warning.

As a child I would often be disturbed if my routine changed and I struggled very much if I had to wear things like new clothes and if I had to get rid of old clothes.  I'd describe the sensation of wearing something uncomfortable as 'feeling like diarrhea', which is obviously an odd expression.

If it turns out I do have autism, I don't think it's truly severe, but all the conditions together are having a major impact on me mentally and physically.  I dated a girl with severe Asperger's syndrome and I struggled, as she self-harmed.  I too have a history of suicide attempts.

At present I am just very confused what to do about things.  I come from a family where maintaining a public face is very important and hiding feelings, emotions and being seen to be 'normal' is very important, but it's a family full of mental health issues.

I'm basically looking for advice, assistance and any help people can give.  I hope my experience can also be of some help and assistance to other people.

HopeforMiami.bio:
I've been living with anxiety and MDD for about 16 years.  
I was a regular happy, curious, creative professional. I loved my career, had my hobbies, and loved doing creative things with my kids and watching them grow into little individuals. 
I also have ADHD, non-attentive type and was really naive and clueless about people.

My ADD makes me more naive than I already am. So I ended up realizing, much too late, that I was in a psychologically and emotionally abusive relationship.  

During the last 2 years a lot of bad things confligrated and I ended up with PTSD. My neurochemistry was permanently damaged and it felt like I was going crazy. I couldn't even tell what I was nervous about or crying about.

It was almost 20 years and I was in love and we had great times together.  During the last five years, a friend called me and I started finding out about cheating, lying and eventually drug addiction. 
We separated for 2 years, but we had a child together and I didn't want him to have an addict Dad. And maybe I hoped that things could change and we might heal.  
I forced him to get help through the Marchmant Act, and during treatment things got really bad.  He was really mean, secretive, manipulative, emotionally abusive. I had to get him to move out. 
He stalked me, hid recorders in the house and in my car, he would call me at night and tell me what I was watching on TV and talking about on the phone. He hid in my back yard and would later call me to tell me whatever he heard and saw me doing.

At the same time, my Mom was battling cancer and died. My aunt also died and my house was in foreclosure because I am and interior architect and designer and the recession basically stopped any new projects and I had no income for a long time.

There were other traumatic situations with my older kids, and I was trying to get closure with my Mom about my real Dad (someone other than I was raised to believe) before she passed, but I couldn't.

I started to fall apart, crying all the time.  I was hyper alert and nervous from the stalking. He would show up anytime, anywhere.  
At one point, I talked to him, crying and begged him to please stop because I felt like I was breaking inside. He just watched me talking and crying with empty eyes and I knew the hell was not going to end. 

He continued his mental abuse through an unnecessary custody battle, manipulating everything and everyone he could, including my family, trying to make it seem as though I was crazy.  I still have nightmares about him all these years later.
At the end of foreclosure, the person who bought my house said they would help me find a rental. And when I got an eviction notice, they said it was just a formality and not to worry.  
Soon after that a truck pulled up and started putting all my furniture out on the front lawn and stuffing big black garbage bags with my things. My friend called me and I was incoherent, so she called my family to come help.

I've picked up most of the pieces, and tried to do my best for my son, never even told people how bad things were with his Dad to protect him from hearing any gossip. 
My relationship with my older kids and my sisters has suffered. They don't want to deal with my trauma, anxiety and depression, so they just avoid me.  
I don't think society is very kind. I don't really want to risk myself in any more relationships, I can't watch the news anymore, and I feel like I'm a shadow of who I used to be.  
I don't mind solitude, but it's painful not to belong anywhere. I'm becoming less functional, and I don't think I can keep supporting myself. And I wonder how many people have been in my situation, with no way out except going to sleep permanently.
